Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: '''Natasha Elizabeth Dupeyrón Estrada''' (born 3 June 1991 in [[Mexico City]], [[Distrito Federal]], Mexico),<ref name=\"esmas\"/> known professionally as '''Natasha Dupeyron''', is a [[Mexican people
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Mexican]] actress, singer, and spokesmodel. She has acted in various Mexican telenovelas since childhood. Dupeyrón was a member of the Mexican-Argentine pop band, [[Eme 15]] from 2011 until 2014.<ref name=\"radioformula.com.mx\">{{cite web
column5: title=Dará EME 15 último concierto en Acapulco, señala Paulina Goto. Con Maxine Woodside

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Dupeyrón was born in Mexico City to Mexican actor, Humberto Dupeyrón and María de los Ángeles Estrada Luévano. She has one older brother, one younger brother, and one older sister.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Natasha Dupeyrón habló sobre la esclerosis múltiple de su papá :: TVNotas !Irresistible!
column9: accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref> The Dupeyrón family traces part of their ancestry to a man who fled the [[French Revolution]] and later settled in [[Tabasco]],<ref>{{cite web
column13: accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref> and the family has been involved in acting in Mexico and Central America for eight generations. Many of Dupeyrón's relatives are also actors including her father, paternal aunt, Elizabeth Dupeyrón and her siblings Odín, Odette, and Osterlen. She was educated at an all-girls Catholic school in Mexico City.<ref>{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Dupeyrón received her first acting role as an extra, in the telenovela, ''Doctor Cándido Pérez'', when she was just 20 days old.<ref name=\"esmas\"/> Since childhood, she has participated in numerous roles in telenovelas, television, theatre, and films. She starred in many famous children's telenovelas such as ''Peregrina'', ''Carita de ángel'', and ''De pocas, Pocas Pulgas''. In addition to television credits, Natasha also participated in ten theatre productions. She starred as ''Chiquis'' in the 2006 Mexican theatre production of ''Vaselina'' (''Grease'' in Spanish) alongside Mexican actors, [[Sherlyn]] and [[Aarón Díaz]]. She performed in 100 productions of ''Vaselina''. Following her role in ''Vaselina'', Dupeyron was cast in her first adolescent role as the wealthy rebellious teenager, \"Marión Von Ferdinand\", in the 2007 Mexican telenovela ''[[Lola...Érase una vez]]''.<ref>{{cite web
In 2008, she was cast as the blind teenager, \"Lia\", in the popular telenovela, ''[[Juro Que Te Amo]]''.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Natasha Dupeyrón, muy entusiasmada con 'Juro que te amo'
column5: accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref> The following year, she starred alongside [[Dulce Maria]] in the telenovela ''[[Verano de Amor]]'' as ''Berenice''. Filming for ''[[Verano de Amor]]'' was conducted in [[Tlacotalpan, Veracruz]] during the summer of 2009.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Televisa.com | Sitio oficial de Televisa para Estados Unidos, con noticias e información exclusiva
column9: accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref> In 2011, she appeared in the music video \"El tiempo no lo cambiará\" for the Mexican singer, Matteos.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In 2010, [[Pedro Damián]] announced plans to produce a remake of the famous 1987 telenovela ''Quinceañera''. Natasha was cast as one of three female protagonists for the new version of ''Quinceanera'' called ''[[Miss XV]]''. [[Danna Paola]] and Renanta Notni were also cast in the project as the remaining protagonists.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Paulina Goto y Eleazar Gómez protagonizarán Miss XV – Univision Novelas y Series
column5: accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref> However, the project was later reformatted and recast in June 2011. Both Paola and Notni were dropped from the project once casting became finalized in July 2011.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Representa 'Miss XV' un gran reto para Natasha Dupeyrón
column10: accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref> Natasha remained an original cast member. [[Paulina Goto]], Elezar Gómez, Yago Muñoz, Jack Duarte and Argentine newcomer, Macarena Achaga, were all cast as main characters in the teen musical television series, ''Miss XV''.<ref>{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: ''Miss XV'' began filming in October 2011 in Mexico City and concluded in June 2012.  The series had 120 episodes. Due to the show's success, a second season or spin-off idea was considered by producers, however, the idea was later rejected.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Los Chicos de Eme 15 quieren madurar
column5: accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref> The program debuted on [[Nickelodeon Latin America]] on 16 April 2012. On 5 May 2012, it began airing on [[Canal 5 (Televisa Network)
column8: title=La euforia de 'Miss XV' ha comenzado

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: On 24 April 2013, Dupeyron, along with her ''Miss XV'' co-star and [[Eme 15]] band mate, [[Paulina Goto]], were announced as protagonists in producer Pedro Damian's newest telenovela, ''Las Mejores Amigas Best Friends Forever''. Although not a spin-off or second season of ''Miss XV'', the program was slated to include songs performed by Eme 15, the band featured on ''Miss XV''. The project was expected to have between 80 and 100 episodes, but it was later canceled for unknown reasons.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Paulina Goto y Natasha Dupeyrón serán 'Las Mejores Amigas' – Terra México

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In November 2012, Dupeyron and her then-boyfriend, actor [[José Pablo Minor]], filmed ''Esencia'', a short film directed by Dupeyron's older brother, Odin, in Mexico City. Mexican actress, singer and model}}: CEA]], where Minor was enrolled as a student before later becoming a full-time actor.<ref>{{Cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In October 2013, Dupeyron was officially confirmed as \"Frida\" in producer Rosy Ocampo's latest telenovela, ''[[Qué pobres tan ricos]]''. The show is a remake of a Colombian telenovela, ''[[Pobres Rico]]''. Filming began in Mexico City in early October and the show premiered in Mexico on 11 November 2013 for [[Canal de las Estrellas]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Más Qué Telenovelas: Natasha Dupeyrón se integra a \"Qué pobres tan ricos\"

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In December 2014, she filmed ''Dentro de la mina'', a zombie horror movie, which is expected to be released sometime in 2015. The film is directed by Juan Antonio de la Riva and Dupeyron plays \"Roberta\". The film was previously called ''Insurgentes Malditos''.  The film's final title was announced as ''Ladrona de almas'' in September 2015.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Tina Romero y Juan Carlos Colombo serán homenajeados en Feratum 2015
column8: title='Natasha Dupeyrón estrena obra \"Infidelidades\" con Erika Buenfil y Laura Flores
column11: accessdate=16 January 2015}}</ref> In early January 2015, she appeared in a music video, \"Contigo puedo see quién soy\", with Mexican singer, Juan Solo, for his upcoming album, ''Ni Solo Ni Mal Acompañado''.  The music video premiered on 12 February 2015 on Solo's official YouTube channel.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=\"Ni Solo Ni Mal Acompañado\" un disco mucho más latino: Juan Solo
column18: title=Juan Solo y Natasha Dupeyrón en 'Contigo puedo ser quien soy'
column21: accessdate=25 January 2015}}</ref> In January 2015, she began rehearsing for the play, ''Buen Viaje'', where she alternated as the female lead. The play debuted on 8 January 2015 and ended on 8 February 2015.  Performances were held from Thursdays to Saturdays at Teatro en Corto in the [[Colonia Nápoles]] neighborhood in Mexico City. In February 2015, she appeared in an episode of the YouTube series, \"Querido Hijo de Puta\", a monologue episodic skit, directed and produced by her older brother, Odin. Dupeyron also co-starred in the play, ''Infidelidades'', alongside actresses Erika Buenfil and Laura Flores. It is a Spanish-language adaptation based on the [[Woody Allen]] play, \"Central Park West\". The play premiered at Teatro Libanés in Mexico City on 20 February 2015.<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=Arranca temporada de Teatro en Corto
column27: title=Baja Omar Fierro 19 kilos ante posible entrada a \"México Baila
column32: title=Natasha Dupeyron habla sobre su debut en cine de terror
column37: title=Disfruta Natasha-Dupeyron retarse como actriz en el-teatro
column40: accessdate=25 January 2015}}</ref> After appearing in 100 performances of \"Infidelidades\", Dupeyron ended her run in the play on 29 June 2015 due to her rehearsal schedule for the musical, \"La Llamada\". She later rejoined the cast for two special performances held on [[Broadway theatre
column41: Broadway]] in New York City on 22 August 2015.<ref>{{cite web
column43: title=Recibirá Erika Buenfil premio por \"Infidelidades\" en EU

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: On 9 February 2015, she was announced as lead cast member for the play, \"La Llamada\". The musical comedy, set at a Catholic summer camp, is an adaptation based on the critically acclaimed Spanish play of the same name. The play premiered on 28 August 2015, and performances were held at Teatro López Tarso in Mexico City until November 2015.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Natasha Dupeyrón, lista para regresar a la música

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Dupeyrón was a member of the Mexican-Argentine musical group [[Eme 15]], which was composed of the six lead actors from the television series, ''[[Miss XV]]''. The other five members were [[Paulina Goto]], Elezar Gómez, [[Macarena Achaga]], Yago Muñoz, and [[Jack Duarte]]. The band performed songs presented on the show. Their debut performance was at Mexico's ''Kids Choice Awards'' on 3 September 2011 in Mexico City. They performed their first single, ''Wonderland''.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=M-15: el nuevo RBD de Pedro Damián
column6: accessdate=9 October 2014}}</ref> During a September 2013 live video chat with fans, Dupeyron denied claims that she would continue a career as a solo singer following [[Eme 15]]'s then-rumored separation. Instead, she expressed that she was more comfortable with acting rather than pursuing a singing career professionally.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: On 18 December 2013, it was officially announced to fans via the band's official Twitter account that the band would split up, following their final concert on 5 January 2014 at the Mega Feria Imperial de Acapulco in [[Acapulco]], Mexico.<ref name=\"radioformula.com.mx\"/>

Dupeyron studied piano and violin during her childhood. She began learning the ukulele in 2015. She is a supporter of animal and feminist rights. She currently resides in Mexico City. She was in a relationship with actor Eddy Vilard from 2008 to 2011.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Coinciden Eddy Vilard y Natasha Dupeyrón en castings
column6: accessdate=29 July 2017}}</ref> From 2012 until late 2015, she dated Mexican actor, [[José Pablo Minor]].<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Desea José Pablo Minor convertirse en productor de cine
column11: accessdate=11 April 2016}}</ref> In June 2014, she briefly relocated to [[Boston]], Massachusetts to study English in a summer course for three months. She returned to Mexico City in mid-August of the same year.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=En ¡HOLA!: Natasha Dupeyrón y José Pablo Minor protagonizan una romántica sesión de fotos

column11: accessdate=11 October 2015}}</ref> In December 2015, she traveled to [[Chiapas]] to film a small role in the upcoming Mexican soccer-themed romantic comedy movie, \"Túnel 19\", since renamed \"El que busca encuentra\".<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Se graban escenas de \"Túnel 19\" en San Cristóbal

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: On 25 January 2016, she was confirmed as a cast member for \"Realidad aumentada\", a Mexican television drama series directed by Jesus Magana, Luis Eduardo Reyes, Alejandro Iglesias and Jorge Aragon. The show filmed until the spring of 2016.  The series is now called ''M.I.N.T.'', but does not yet have a release date.  She filmed a role in the Mexican film, \"La vida immoral de la pareja ideal\", in [[San Miguel de Allende]], Mexico in February 2016. The movie was released in Mexican cinemas on 28 October 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Manolo Caro presenta 'La vida inmoral de la pareja ideal'
column8: title=Juan Diego Covarrubias hará serie \"Realidad aumentada\"
column13: title=\"La vida inmoral de la pareja ideal\" llegará a salas comerciales
column16: accessdate=20 February 2016}}</ref> Dupeyron voiced the character, \"Katie\", for the Latin American Spanish-language dub of the 2016 animated film, [[The Secret Life of Pets]].<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=Natasha Dupeyron prestará su voz para una película animada

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: She was cast in the Mexican drama film, \"Plan V\", which began filming in Mexico City in mid-December 2016. Filming was also conducted in [[Guadalajara]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Arranca filmación de Plan V en Guadalajara con Natasha Dupeyron
column6: accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref> The movie is expected to be released in February 2018.<ref>{{cite web
column11: accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref> In June 2017, she was cast in a series that is slated to air in 2018. On 21 June 2017, she received a nomination for \"Revelación femenina\" (Best female revolution) for her work in the movie, [[:es:Treintona, soltera y fantástica
column12: Treintona, soltera y fantástica]], at the [[59th Ariel Awards]], the Mexican film industry's equivalent of the [[Academy Award]]. The award show was held on 11 July 2017 at the [[Palacio de Bellas Artes]] in Mexico City. Dupeyron did not win.<ref>{{cite web
column15: publisher=Academia Mexicana de Artes y Ciencias Cinematográficas
column22: title=Natasha Dupeyrón prepara serie para platforma digital

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In late June 2017, she participated in the improvisation theatre series, \"M.I.N.D.\" (Material Inédito No Degradable).<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Natasha Dupeyrón por primera vez hará sketches; será en la obra \"M.I.N.D.\"
column6: accessdate=29 July 2017}}</ref> In July 2017, Dupeyron was cast in the Mexican adaptation of the Broadway play, [[Closer (play)
column7: Closer]], by [[Patrick Marber]]. The play is scheduled to run for 10 weeks starting on 18 August 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Cine y teatro se van de la mano

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: From 2009 to 2012, Dupeyron modeled clothing for the women's collections in the popular print catalogue, ''Cklass'' in Mexico. In September 2012, she signed a contract as the newest spokesmodel for [[Maybelline]] cosmetics in Mexico. She appears in TV and print ads for ''Pure + Makeup'' line.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Natasha Dupeyron más bella que nunca
column8: title=Natasha Dupeyrón fue elegida imagen de la marca Maybelline | starMedia
column11: accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref> In May 2013, she became the newest image for the [[Garnier Fructis]] ''100% color de Garnier'' campaign in Mexico. Dupeyrón appeared in print and commercials to promote the hair color brand in Mexico.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In September 2014, she appeared in a national camping called \"No te hagas güey\" alongside other Mexican artists such as [[Sherlyn González]] and Daniela Magun. The campaign's aims to raise awareness against underage alcohol consumption in Mexico.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=No te hagas güey: Cerveceros a padres de menores

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In 2003, Dupeyron and the other child actors from cast of the children's telenovela, ''De Pocas Pulgas Pulgas Pulgas'', recorded two albums of music featured on the program and embarked on a tour of Latin America to promote the show.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Ya tienen su disco los de 'Pocas pulgas'

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Dupeyrón was a member of the Mexican-Argentine musical group [[Eme 15]], which was composed of the six lead actors from the television series, ''[[Miss XV]]''. The other five members were [[Paulina Goto]], Elezar Gómez, [[Macarena Achaga]], Yago Muñoz, and [[Jack Duarte]]. The band performed songs presented on the show. Their debut performance was at Mexico's ''Kids Choice Awards'' on 3 September 2011 in Mexico City. They performed their first single, ''Wonderland''.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=M-15: el nuevo RBD de Pedro Damián
column6: accessdate=9 October 2014}}</ref> During a September 2013 live video chat with fans, Dupeyron denied claims that she would continue a career as a solo singer following [[Eme 15]]'s then-rumored separation. Instead, she expressed that she was more comfortable with acting rather than pursuing a singing career professionally.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: On 18 December 2013, it was officially announced to fans via the band's official Twitter account that the band would split up, following their final concert on 5 January 2014 at the Mega Feria Imperial de Acapulco in [[Acapulco]], Mexico.<ref name=\"radioformula.com.mx\"/>

Dupeyron studied piano and violin during her childhood. She began learning the ukulele in 2015. She is a supporter of animal and feminist rights. She currently resides in Mexico City. She was in a relationship with actor Eddy Vilard from 2008 to 2011.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Coinciden Eddy Vilard y Natasha Dupeyrón en castings
column6: accessdate=29 July 2017}}</ref> From 2012 until late 2015, she dated Mexican actor, [[José Pablo Minor]].<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Desea José Pablo Minor convertirse en productor de cine
column11: accessdate=11 April 2016}}</ref> In June 2014, she briefly relocated to [[Boston]], Massachusetts to study English in a summer course for three months. She returned to Mexico City in mid-August of the same year.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=En ¡HOLA!: Natasha Dupeyrón y José Pablo Minor protagonizan una romántica sesión de fotos

column3: title=En ¡HOLA!: Natasha Dupeyrón y Yago Muñoz se casaron, después de 10 años de amistad

column9: accessdate=20 May 2019}}</ref> They were placed in [[2003 FIFA Women's World Cup Group C
column10: Group C]] alongside South American runners-up [[Argentina women's national football team
column11: Argentina]], North American runners-up [[Canada women's national soccer team
column12: Canada]], and inter-continental play-off winner [[Japan women's national football team
column17: title=U.S. Has No Luck in Draw
column26: title=The Group Dynamics of the Women's World Cup
column30: accessdate=19 May 2019}}</ref> The team, managed by [[Tina Theune
column31: Tina Theune-Meyer]] and named an early favorite prior to the tournament, usually played in a 4–5–1 with [[Birgit Prinz]] or a 4–4–2 with Prinz and another striker, supported by [[Bettina Wiegmann]] leading the midfield and a roster of younger talent.<ref>{{cite web
column32: title=Germany Profile: It's time for a world title think Germans
column39: accessdate=20 May 2019}}</ref> Germany conceded in the fourth minute of its opening match to Canada's [[Christine Sinclair]], who headed in a free kick, but equalized before half-time from a penalty kick awarded for a handball and taken by Wiegmann. The Germans took the lead early in the second half on a header by [[Stefanie Gottschlich]] in the 47th minute, which was followed by goals by Birgit Prinz and substitute [[Kerstin Garefrekes]] to win 4–1.<ref>{{cite news

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The team won 3–0 in their second match against Japan, taking first place in Group C with six points, by using its physical advantage and sustained attacks. [[Sandra Minnert]] scored in the 23rd minute on a rebound and was followed by strikes from Prinz in the 36th and 66th minutes.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Germans don't waste size advantage while raising record to 2-0
column7: work=The Columbus Dispatch}}</ref> Germany advanced to the knockout stage atop Group C by defeating Argentina 6–1 in their third match, earning nine points and outscoring opponents 13–2. The [[blowout (sports)
column8: rout]] of Argentina began in the third minute with a goal for [[Maren Meinert]], which was followed by another for her, a penalty for Wiegmann, and a half-volley for Prinz in the first half. The team lost defender [[Steffi Jones]] to a knee injury in the second half and conceded a consolation goal to Argentina before scoring twice at the end of the match to extend their lead.<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Germany prevails, 6-1, but defender Jones out

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Germany played in the quarter-finals against [[Russia women's national football team
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Russia]], runners-up of Group D, at [[PGE Park]] in [[Portland, Oregon]]. The team only managed a 1–0 lead at half-time, following a goal by [[Martina Müller (footballer)
column3: Martina Müller]] in the 25th minute, due to the strong defense offered by the Russians. Germany broke through early in the second half and scored thrice in a five-minute span, including strikes by Minnert, substitute [[Pia Wunderlich]], and Garefrekes. Russia scored a consolation goal in the 70th minute, but Germany scored another trio of goals in the last ten minutes—one more from Garefrekes and two from Prinz.<ref>{{cite news
column7: title=Women's World Cup: Germany joins the party

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In the semi-finals, Germany faced the [[United States women's national soccer team
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: United States]] and defeated them 3–0 in a major [[upset (sports)
column3: upset]] of the defending champions and hosts.<ref>{{cite news
column11: accessdate=21 May 2019}}</ref> Kerstin Garefrekes's header off a corner kick in the 15th minute opened the scoring for the Germans, while the United States responded by switching to an attack-minded 3–4–3 in the second half and squandered several chances to equalize, forcing saves out of goalkeeper [[Silke Rottenberg]]. The Americans pushed forward and left themselves open to counter-attacks, conceding two goals in stoppage time on breakaways that were scored by Meinert and Prinz.<ref>{{cite news
column23: title=US women are out of business

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Sweden finished first in its qualification group, winning five matches and losing one with a 27–4 goal differential to best runners-up [[Denmark women's national football team
column3: title=2003 FIFA Women's World Cup Preliminaries: UEFA Group 2
column14: title=Kickoff Foe Is Familiar to U.S.
column19: accessdate=20 May 2019}} {{free access}}</ref> They played in [[2003 FIFA Women's World Cup Group A
column20: Group A]], which was dubbed the [[Group of death]] for the strong lineup of defending world champions and hosts United States, African champions [[Nigeria women's national football team
column21: Nigeria]], and Asian champions [[North Korea women's national football team
column26: title=Cup won't come easy for U.S. women
column33: title=Women's World Cup teams at a glance
column38: accessdate=20 May 2019}} {{free access}}</ref> Sweden lost 3–1 in their opening match against the United States in [[Washington, D.C.]], conceding twice in the first half to goals scored by [[Kristine Lilly]] and [[Cindy Parlow]], both assisted by [[Mia Hamm]]. The lead was cut to 2–1 in the 55th minute by [[Victoria Sandell Svensson]], who finished a long pass from [[Hanna Ljungberg]], but American forward [[Shannon Boxx]] scored in the 78th minute to give the hosts a victory.<ref>{{cite news

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Four days later in Philadelphia, Sweden defeated North Korea 1–0 with an early goal scored by Svensson in the seventh minute, tying them for second place in the group.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Svensson's goal sends Sweden over N. Korea
column8: accessdate=19 May 2019}} {{free access}}</ref> Sweden finished second in Group A and advanced to the quarter-finals after their 3–0 victory over Nigeria in [[Columbus, Ohio]], scoring all three goals coming in the second half. Ljungberg scored twice in the 56th and 79th minutes, the former a header and latter a shot off a pass by [[Therese Sjoegran]], and captain [[Malin Moström]] scored in the 81st minute on a breakaway.<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Strong second half lifts Sweden to win

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In the quarter-finals at [[Gillette Stadium]], Sweden faced [[Brazil women's national football team
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Brazil]], who had previously defeated them in the [[1995 FIFA Women's World Cup
column3: 1995 World Cup]] and [[Football at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament
column6: title=Shutout gives Sweden berth in quarterfinals
column12: accessdate=19 May 2019}} {{free access}}</ref> Svensson opened the scoring on a counterattack in the 23rd minute, but Brazil equalized before half-time through a penalty kick taken by [[Marta (footballer)
column13: Marta]] after she was tripped by goalkeeper [[Sofia Lundgren]], who had replaced starting goalkeeper [[Caroline Jönsson]]. Sweden were awarded a free kick {{convert
column16: m}} from the goal in the 53rd minute, which was converted into a goal by [[Malin Andersson]], while the team resisted several chances from Brazil to defeat them 2–1.<ref>{{cite news

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The Swedes then played in the semi-finals against Canada, who had earned an upset victory over China in the quarter-finals.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Women's World Cup: Whoa, Canada pulls upset
column7: work=The Oregonian}}</ref> The match remained scoreless in the first half and the deadlock was broken in the 64th minute by Canadian midfielder [[Kara Lang]], who took a free kick from {{convert
column10: m}} that slipped out of the hands of Jönsson and spun into the goal.<ref>{{cite news
column14: title=Women's World Cup: Sweden's late goals break through Canada
column16: work=The Oregonian}}</ref> Swedish manager [[Marika Domanski-Lyfors]] used all three of her substitutions to bring on more attackers, and the equalizer was scored in the 79th minute by Malin Moström from a free kick. Substitute forward [[Josefine Öqvist]] scored the winning goal for Sweden six minutes later, finishing a rebound off a shot by Hanna Ljungberg that was saved by goalkeeper [[Taryn Swiatek]].<ref>{{cite news
column20: title=Close Just Doesn't Count for Canada

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The 2003 final was played at the [[Home Depot Center]], a 27,000-seat stadium in the [[Los Angeles]] suburb of [[Carson, California]]. The stadium was opened on 7 June 2003 as one of the first American venues to be [[soccer-specific stadium
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: designed primarily for soccer]], serving as the home of the [[Los Angeles Galaxy]] of [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS).<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Absolutely No Place Like Home for Galaxy

column14: title=For U.S. Women, Two Trips to China

column22: title=U.S. Replaces China As Host of Soccer's Women's World Cup
column26: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> The Home Depot Center was chosen in June to host four matches during the group stage, the third place play-off, and the final.<ref>{{cite news
column30: title=Venues set: Carson, Calif., to host final
column40: title=Women's World Cup to kick off in Phila.
column45: accessdate=18 May 2019}} {{free access}}</ref> The Home Depot Center was also selected as the host of the [[MLS Cup]] in [[MLS Cup 2003
column51: title=MLS Cup: Earthquakes rumble; Donovan, Onstad secure S.J.'s 2nd title
column57: title=Home Depot Center to host MLS Cup

column7: work=The Columbus Dispatch}}</ref> Germany advanced to the knockout stage atop Group C by defeating Argentina 6–1 in their third match, earning nine points and outscoring opponents 13–2. The [[blowout (sports)
column8: rout]] of Argentina began in the third minute with a goal for [[Maren Meinert]], which was followed by another for her, a penalty for Wiegmann, and a half-volley for Prinz in the first half. The team lost defender [[Steffi Jones]] to a knee injury in the second half and conceded a consolation goal to Argentina before scoring twice at the end of the match to extend their lead.<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Germany prevails, 6-1, but defender Jones out

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Germany played in the quarter-finals against [[Russia women's national football team
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Russia]], runners-up of Group D, at [[PGE Park]] in [[Portland, Oregon]]. The team only managed a 1–0 lead at half-time, following a goal by [[Martina Müller (footballer)
column3: Martina Müller]] in the 25th minute, due to the strong defense offered by the Russians. Germany broke through early in the second half and scored thrice in a five-minute span, including strikes by Minnert, substitute [[Pia Wunderlich]], and Garefrekes. Russia scored a consolation goal in the 70th minute, but Germany scored another trio of goals in the last ten minutes—one more from Garefrekes and two from Prinz.<ref>{{cite news
column7: title=Women's World Cup: Germany joins the party

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In the semi-finals, Germany faced the [[United States women's national soccer team
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: United States]] and defeated them 3–0 in a major [[upset (sports)
column3: upset]] of the defending champions and hosts.<ref>{{cite news
column11: accessdate=21 May 2019}}</ref> Kerstin Garefrekes's header off a corner kick in the 15th minute opened the scoring for the Germans, while the United States responded by switching to an attack-minded 3–4–3 in the second half and squandered several chances to equalize, forcing saves out of goalkeeper [[Silke Rottenberg]]. The Americans pushed forward and left themselves open to counter-attacks, conceding two goals in stoppage time on breakaways that were scored by Meinert and Prinz.<ref>{{cite news
column23: title=US women are out of business

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Sweden finished first in its qualification group, winning five matches and losing one with a 27–4 goal differential to best runners-up [[Denmark women's national football team
column3: title=2003 FIFA Women's World Cup Preliminaries: UEFA Group 2
column14: title=Kickoff Foe Is Familiar to U.S.
column19: accessdate=20 May 2019}} {{free access}}</ref> They played in [[2003 FIFA Women's World Cup Group A
column20: Group A]], which was dubbed the [[Group of death]] for the strong lineup of defending world champions and hosts United States, African champions [[Nigeria women's national football team
column21: Nigeria]], and Asian champions [[North Korea women's national football team
column26: title=Cup won't come easy for U.S. women
column33: title=Women's World Cup teams at a glance
column38: accessdate=20 May 2019}} {{free access}}</ref> Sweden lost 3–1 in their opening match against the United States in [[Washington, D.C.]], conceding twice in the first half to goals scored by [[Kristine Lilly]] and [[Cindy Parlow]], both assisted by [[Mia Hamm]]. The lead was cut to 2–1 in the 55th minute by [[Victoria Sandell Svensson]], who finished a long pass from [[Hanna Ljungberg]], but American forward [[Shannon Boxx]] scored in the 78th minute to give the hosts a victory.<ref>{{cite news

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Four days later in Philadelphia, Sweden defeated North Korea 1–0 with an early goal scored by Svensson in the seventh minute, tying them for second place in the group.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Svensson's goal sends Sweden over N. Korea
column8: accessdate=19 May 2019}} {{free access}}</ref> Sweden finished second in Group A and advanced to the quarter-finals after their 3–0 victory over Nigeria in [[Columbus, Ohio]], scoring all three goals coming in the second half. Ljungberg scored twice in the 56th and 79th minutes, the former a header and latter a shot off a pass by [[Therese Sjoegran]], and captain [[Malin Moström]] scored in the 81st minute on a breakaway.<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Strong second half lifts Sweden to win

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In the quarter-finals at [[Gillette Stadium]], Sweden faced [[Brazil women's national football team
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Brazil]], who had previously defeated them in the [[1995 FIFA Women's World Cup
column3: 1995 World Cup]] and [[Football at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament
column6: title=Shutout gives Sweden berth in quarterfinals
column12: accessdate=19 May 2019}} {{free access}}</ref> Svensson opened the scoring on a counterattack in the 23rd minute, but Brazil equalized before half-time through a penalty kick taken by [[Marta (footballer)
column13: Marta]] after she was tripped by goalkeeper [[Sofia Lundgren]], who had replaced starting goalkeeper [[Caroline Jönsson]]. Sweden were awarded a free kick {{convert
column16: m}} from the goal in the 53rd minute, which was converted into a goal by [[Malin Andersson]], while the team resisted several chances from Brazil to defeat them 2–1.<ref>{{cite news

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The Swedes then played in the semi-finals against Canada, who had earned an upset victory over China in the quarter-finals.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Women's World Cup: Whoa, Canada pulls upset
column7: work=The Oregonian}}</ref> The match remained scoreless in the first half and the deadlock was broken in the 64th minute by Canadian midfielder [[Kara Lang]], who took a free kick from {{convert
column10: m}} that slipped out of the hands of Jönsson and spun into the goal.<ref>{{cite news
column14: title=Women's World Cup: Sweden's late goals break through Canada
column16: work=The Oregonian}}</ref> Swedish manager [[Marika Domanski-Lyfors]] used all three of her substitutions to bring on more attackers, and the equalizer was scored in the 79th minute by Malin Moström from a free kick. Substitute forward [[Josefine Öqvist]] scored the winning goal for Sweden six minutes later, finishing a rebound off a shot by Hanna Ljungberg that was saved by goalkeeper [[Taryn Swiatek]].<ref>{{cite news
column20: title=Close Just Doesn't Count for Canada

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The 2003 final was played at the [[Home Depot Center]], a 27,000-seat stadium in the [[Los Angeles]] suburb of [[Carson, California]]. The stadium was opened on 7 June 2003 as one of the first American venues to be [[soccer-specific stadium
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: designed primarily for soccer]], serving as the home of the [[Los Angeles Galaxy]] of [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS).<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Absolutely No Place Like Home for Galaxy
column10: accessdate=18 May 2019}}</ref> The final was originally planned to take place at [[Hongkou Football Stadium]] in [[Shanghai]], China,<ref>{{cite news
column14: title=For U.S. Women, Two Trips to China
column18: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> but the tournament was moved to the United States after China's withdrawal in April 2003 due to the outbreak of [[SARS]].<ref>{{cite news
column22: title=U.S. Replaces China As Host of Soccer's Women's World Cup
column26: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> The Home Depot Center was chosen in June to host four matches during the group stage, the third place play-off, and the final.<ref>{{cite news
column30: title=Venues set: Carson, Calif., to host final
column40: title=Women's World Cup to kick off in Phila.
column45: accessdate=18 May 2019}} {{free access}}</ref> The Home Depot Center was also selected as the host of the [[MLS Cup]] in [[MLS Cup 2003
column51: title=MLS Cup: Earthquakes rumble; Donovan, Onstad secure S.J.'s 2nd title
column57: title=Home Depot Center to host MLS Cup

column5: title=Homes for Sale – Bel Air, CA
column7: accessdate=September 12, 2017}}</ref> and the ''Los Angeles Times''  use ''Bel-Air''<ref>{{cite news
column14: title=Thomas Guide: Los Angeles County Street Guide & Directory
column18: isbn=978-1-58174-339-5}}</ref>}} is a [[neighborhood]] on the [[Los Angeles Westside
column19: Westside of Los Angeles, California]], in the foothills of the [[Santa Monica Mountains]].  Founded in 1923, it is the home of The [[Hannah Carter Japanese Garden]] and the [[American Jewish University]].

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The community was founded in 1923 by [[Alphonzo Bell]]. Bell owned farm property in [[Santa Fe Springs, California]], where oil was discovered. He bought a large ranch with a home on what is now Bel Air Road. He subdivided and developed the property with large residential lots, with work on the master plan led by the landscape architect [[Mark Daniels]].<ref name=thompson>{{cite web
column5: title=Mark Daniels excelled in developing and marketing scenic beauty
column7: date=April 18, 2007}}</ref> He also built the [[Bel-Air Bay Club]] in [[Pacific Palisades, Los Angeles
column8: Pacific Palisades]] and the [[Bel-Air Country Club]]. His wife chose Italian names for the streets. She also founded the Bel-Air Garden Club in 1931.<ref>{{cite web

Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Beverly Hills]] and [[Holmby Hills]], Bel Air forms the [[Platinum Triangle, Los Angeles
column3: Platinum Triangle]] of Los Angeles neighborhoods.<ref>{{cite news
column7: title=No housing slump for super-rich – sales and prices have never been better in the Platinum Triangle

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: On November 6, 1961, a fire ignited and devastated the community of Bel Air, destroying 484 homes in the area.{{r
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: LAT 2005/mar/06}} On December 6, 2017, a fire started by a homeless encampment burned in the same area, destroying six homes.

column4: km}} west of [[Downtown Los Angeles]]<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Driving Directions from Los Angeles, CA to Bel Air, CA
column8: accessdate=January 14, 2013}}</ref> and includes some of the foothills of the [[Santa Monica Mountains]]. It lies across [[Sunset Boulevard]] from the northern edge of the main campus of the [[University of California, Los Angeles]]. At the heart of the community sits the [[Bel-Air Country Club]] and the [[Hotel Bel-Air]].{{citation needed

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Along with [[Beverly Hills]] and the Los Angeles community of [[Brentwood, Los Angeles
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Brentwood]], Bel Air is part of a high-priced area on the Westside known as the \"three Bs.\"<ref name=BDSp347>{{cite book
column9: chapter=Middle Easterners: A New Kind of Immigrant
column20: quote=...in Beverly Hills, Bel Air, and Brentwood, known in local parlance as 'the three Bs.'}}</ref><ref>{{cite news
column27: quote=Each map tends to cover the 'three Bs': Brentwood, Bel-Air and Beverly Hills. A few toss in a Malibu sidebar.}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news
column31: title=A Sad Westside Story : Home Prices Have Declined as Much as 50% Since the 1980s
column35: quote=But, as Meyer's case suggests, nowhere have those losses been as dramatic as the high-priced area on the Westside known as the 'three Bs' – Brentwood, Bel-Air and Beverly Hills.}}</ref>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: This region experiences warm and dry summers.  According to the [[Köppen Climate Classification]] system, Bel Air has a [[Mediterranean climate#Warm-summer Mediterranean climate
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: warm-summer Mediterranean climate]], abbreviated \"Csb\" on climate maps.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Climate Summary for Bel Air, California

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The 2000 U.S. census counted 7,691 residents in the {{convert
column6: /sqmi}} it has among the lowest [[population densities]] for the city and the county. In 2008, the city estimated that the population had increased to 8,253.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In 2000 the median age for residents was 46, which was high for city and county neighborhoods. The percentages of residents aged 50 and older was among the county's highest.<ref name=MappingLABelAir>{{cite web

The median yearly household income in 2008 was $207,938, the highest figure for any [[neighborhood]] or [[city]] in Los Angeles County. Renters occupied 14.5% of the housing stock, and house- or apartment-owners held 85.5%. The average household size of 2.4 people was considered typical for Los Angeles.<ref name=MappingLABelAir/>

The 4.1% of families headed by single parents was considered low for city and county neighborhoods. The percentages of married people in Bel Air were among the county's highest—66.0% for men and 65.7% for women. There were 808 veterans, or 12.9% of the population.<ref name=MappingLABelAir/><ref>{{cite web
The neighborhood was considered \"not especially diverse\" ethnically<ref>{{cite web
column6: quote=The diversity index measures the probability that any two residents, chosen at random, would be of different ethnicities. If all residents are of the same ethnic group it's zero. If half are from one group and half from another it's .50.\"
column7: accessdate=October 31, 2015}}</ref> within Los Angeles, with a relatively high percentage of white people. The breakdown was [[Non-Hispanic Whites
column11: blacks]], 0.9%; and others, 3.2%. Iran (26.1%) and South Africa (8.2%) were the most common places of birth for the 24.1% of the residents who were born abroad—which was an average percentage for Los Angeles as a whole.<ref name=MappingLABelAir/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Of several entrances, there are two main ones: (1) the [[East Gate Bel Air, Los Angeles
column4: Sunset]] Boulevards and (2) the West Gate at Bellagio Way and [[Sunset Boulevard]], opposite an entrance to [[UCLA]]. Bel Air is generally subdivided into three distinct neighborhoods: [[East Gate Bel Air, Los Angeles
column5: East Gate Old Bel Air]], West Gate Bel Air, and Upper Bel Air.{{r

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Bel Air Estates, the original subdivision of the Bel Air community, is generally bounded by Nimes Road to the north, Sunset Boulevard to the south, Beverly Glen Boulevard to the east and both sides of Bel Air Road to the west.<ref>[http://www.preservation.lacity.org/files/Bel%20Air%20-Beverly%20Crest%20Districts.pdf SurveyLA: Bel Air - Beverly Crest Report Historic Districts, Planning Districts and Multi-Property Resources – 12/05/13]</ref>

The [[Hannah Carter Japanese Garden]] is located in Bel Air. It was inspired by the gardens of [[Kyoto]]. Many structures in the garden—the main gate, garden house, bridges, and shrine—were built in [[Japan]] and reassembled here. Antique stone carvings, water basins and lanterns, as well as the five-tiered [[pagoda]], and key symbolic rocks are also from Japan.<ref name=\"LAT 20150930\">{{cite news
column3: title=UCLA and Hannah Carter heirs settle suit over Japanese garden in Bel-Air

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]] SPA 5 West Area Health Office serves Bel Air.<ref>{{cite web
column4: website=[[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]]

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: It lies within the 5th city council district, represented by [[Paul Koretz]].  It is located in the 90077 (Bel Air Estates & Beverly Glen) ZIP code, which is part of the city of Los Angeles. [[Stone Canyon Reservoir]] lies in the northeastern part of Bel Air. Established in 1994, it serves around 500,000 people. The Bel Air Association has been operational since 1942, dedicated to preserving the aesthetic appearance of the residential community. The Bel Air Association is located at the entrance of the East Gate of Bel Air at 100 Bel Air Road.<ref>{{cite web
[[Los Angeles Fire Department]] Station 71 is in the area.<ref>{{cite web
The [[Los Angeles Police Department]] operates the West Los Angeles Community Police Station at 1663 Butler Avenue, 90025, serving the neighborhood.<ref>{{cite web

column4: The [[American Jewish University]], located in the Bel Air Casiano neighborhood]]

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Almost two-thirds (66.1%) of Bel Air residents aged 25 and older had earned a [[four-year degree]] by 2000, a high percentage for the city and the county. The percentages of residents in that age range with a [[bachelor's degree]] or greater were high for the county.<ref name=MappingLABelAir/> The community is within the [[Los Angeles Unified School District]]. The area is within Board District 4.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=November 24, 2008}}</ref> As of 2009, Steve Zimmer represented the district.<ref>{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In April 1983 an advisory committee of the LAUSD recommended closing eight LAUSD schools, including Bellagio Road School. The committee did not target Fairburn Avenue School in Westwood, as a way of allowing it to preserve its ethnic balance, and so it can take children from Bellagio Road in the event that it closed.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Closing of 8 Schools Recommended, One Near Airport
column8: accessdate=January 16, 2012}}</ref> In August 1983 the board publicly considered closing Bellagio, which had 240 students at the time.<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Board to Consider Closing 4 More Valley Schools
column15: accessdate=January 16, 2012}}</ref> The school's enrollment had been decreasing. In May 1983 the board voted to keep the school open. In February 1984, after the composition of the board had changed, the board voted to close the Bellagio Road School.<ref>{{cite news
column19: title=L.A. Board to Close 5 More Schools

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Bel Air previously housed the Bellagio Road Newcomer School, a 3rd–8th grade school for newly arrived immigrants. In 2002 it had 390 students from Armenia, China, El Salvador, Guatemala, Korea, Russia, and other countries.<ref name=\"Helfand2\">{{cite news
column6: title=$459 Million in Cuts Are Considered for Fiscally Strapped L.A. Schools

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In 2000 the median age for residents was 46, which was high for city and county neighborhoods. The percentages of residents aged 50 and older was among the county's highest.<ref name=MappingLABelAir>{{cite web

The median yearly household income in 2008 was $207,938, the highest figure for any [[neighborhood]] or [[city]] in Los Angeles County. Renters occupied 14.5% of the housing stock, and house- or apartment-owners held 85.5%. The average household size of 2.4 people was considered typical for Los Angeles.<ref name=MappingLABelAir/>

The 4.1% of families headed by single parents was considered low for city and county neighborhoods. The percentages of married people in Bel Air were among the county's highest—66.0% for men and 65.7% for women. There were 808 veterans, or 12.9% of the population.<ref name=MappingLABelAir/><ref>{{cite web
The neighborhood was considered \"not especially diverse\" ethnically<ref>{{cite web
column6: quote=The diversity index measures the probability that any two residents, chosen at random, would be of different ethnicities. If all residents are of the same ethnic group it's zero. If half are from one group and half from another it's .50.\"
column7: accessdate=October 31, 2015}}</ref> within Los Angeles, with a relatively high percentage of white people. The breakdown was [[Non-Hispanic Whites
column11: blacks]], 0.9%; and others, 3.2%. Iran (26.1%) and South Africa (8.2%) were the most common places of birth for the 24.1% of the residents who were born abroad—which was an average percentage for Los Angeles as a whole.<ref name=MappingLABelAir/>

The [[Hannah Carter Japanese Garden]] is located in Bel Air. It was inspired by the gardens of [[Kyoto]]. Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Foods similar to flatbreads in other parts of the world include Chinese [[Bing (bread)
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: bing]] (a wheat flour-based Chinese food with a flattened or disk-like shape); the Indian [[paratha]] (in which fat is incorporated); the Central and South Asian [[naan]] (leavened) and [[roti]] (unleavened); the Sardinian [[Pane carasau
column4: rieska]]. Also worth noting is that throughout Europe there are many similar pies based on the idea of covering flat pastry with cheese, meat, vegetables and seasoning such as the Alsatian [[flammkuchen]], German [[zwiebelkuchen]], and French [[quiche]].

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In 16th-century [[Naples]], a [[galette]] flatbread was referred to as a pizza. Known as the dish for poor people, it was sold in the street and was not considered a kitchen recipe for a long time.<ref>{{cite web
column8: archive-date=2012-12-19}}</ref> This was later replaced by oil, tomatoes (after Europeans came into contact with the Americas) or fish. In 1843, [[Alexandre Dumas]], described the diversity of pizza toppings.<ref name=dumas>{{cite book
column17: accessdate=May 22, 2012}}</ref> An often recounted story holds that on June 11, 1889, to honour the Queen consort of [[Italy]], [[Margherita of Savoy]], the [[Naples
column18: Neapolitan]] pizzamaker [[Raffaele Esposito]] created the \"[[Pizza Margherita]]\", a pizza garnished with tomatoes, [[mozzarella]], and basil, to represent the [[national colours of Italy]] as on the [[Flag of Italy]].<ref>{{cite journal
column32: title=Pizza purists out to protect patriotic pie
column35: date=March 2, 1989}}</ref><!-- p=12A --><!-- NOTE: American Heritage article by Hanna Miller is not a reliable citation for this claim -->

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Pizza evolved into a type of bread and tomato dish, often served with cheese. However, until the late 19th or early 20th century, the dish was sweet, not savory, and earlier versions which were savory more resembled the flat breads now known as [[schiacciata]].<ref>Alexandra Grigorieva,  \"Naming Authenticity and Regional Italian Cuisine [https://books.google.com/books?lr=lang_en&id=HflTVd898PAC&dq=Pellegrino+Artusi&q=pizza#v=snippet&q=pizza&f=false],\" in Richard Hosking, ed., ''Authenticity in the Kitchen: Proceedings of the Oxford Symposium on Food and Cookery 2005'' (Prospect Books, 2006): 211–216.</ref> [[Pellegrino Artusi]]'s classic early-twentieth-century cookbook, ''La Scienza in cucina e l'Arte di mangiar bene'' gives three recipes for pizza, all of which are sweet.<ref>Pellegrino Artusi, ''La scienza in cucina e l'Arte di mangiar bene'' (1911; rpr. Torino: Einaudi, 2001)</ref> After the feedback of some readers, Artusi added a typed sheet in the 1911 edition (discovered by food historian Alberto Capatti), bound with the volume, with the recipe of \"pizza alla napoletana\": mozzarella, tomatoes, anchovies and mushrooms.<ref>Mattozzi, Antonio e Donatella (2016)  \"Pizze, pizzerie e pizzaiuoli a Napoli tra Sette e Ottocento\" p.35, in ''Pizza. Una grande tradizione italiana''. Bra: Slow Food Publisher</ref>
However, by 1927, Ada Boni's collection of regional cooking includes a recipe using tomatoes and mozzarella.<ref>Grigorieva, Naming Authenticity,\" p. 211-212.</ref>

The innovation that led to flat bread pizza was the use of [[tomato]] as a topping. For some time after the tomato was brought to [[Europe]] from the Americas in the 16th century, it was believed by many Europeans to be poisonous, as some other fruits of the ''[[Solanaceae]]'' (nightshade) family are. However, by the late 18th century, it was common for the poor of the area around [[Naples]] to add tomato to their yeast-based flat bread, and so the pizza began.{{citation needed
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: date=November 2014}} The dish gained popularity, and soon pizza became a tourist attraction as visitors to Naples ventured into the poorer areas of the city to try the local specialty.

column4: [[Antica Pizzeria Port'Alba]] in Naples, which is widely believed to be the world's first pizzeria]]

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: According to documents discovered by historian Antonio Mattozzi in State Archive of Naples, in 1807 already 54 pizzerias existed, with their owners and addresses.<ref>Mattozzi, Antonio (2015) ''Inventing the Pizzeria: a History of Pizza Making in Naples'', Bloomsbury Academic, pp.16–17</ref> In the second half of the nineteenth century they increased to 120.<ref>Mattozzi, Antonio  ''Inventing the Pizzeria'', Distribution Maps, p.xxxiv</ref>

In Naples, two others figures connected to the trade existed — the pizza hawker (''pizzaiuolo ambulante''), who sold pizza, but did not make it, and the seller of pizza \"a oggi a otto\", who made pizzas, but sold them in return for a payment for seven days.<ref>Mattozzi, Antonio ''Inventing the Pizzeria'', p.28</ref>
The [[pizza marinara]] method has a topping of tomato, [[oregano]], [[garlic]], and [[Olive oil#Commercial grades
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: extra virgin olive oil]]. It is named \"marinara\" because it was traditionally the food prepared by \"la marinara\", the seaman's wife, for her seafaring husband when he returned from fishing trips in the [[Gulf of Naples

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The margherita is topped with modest amounts of tomato sauce, mozzarella and fresh basil. It is widely attributed to baker [[Raffaele Esposito]], who worked at restaurant \"Pietro... e basta così\" (\"Pietro... and that's enough\"), established in 1880 and still in business as \"Pizzeria Brandi\". Though recent research casts doubt on this legend,<ref>{{cite web

Mexican actress, singer and model}}: title       = Was margherita pizza really named after Italy's queen?

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: }}</ref> the tale holds that, in 1889, he baked three different pizzas for the visit of King [[Umberto I of Italy
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Umberto I]] and Queen [[Margherita of Savoy]]. The Queen's favorite was a pizza evoking the colors of the Italian flag — green ([[basil]] leaves), white ([[mozzarella]]), and red ([[tomato]]es).<ref name=amherit>{{cite news
column5: quote=Cheese, the crowning ingredient, was not added until 1889, when the Royal Palace commissioned the Neapolitan pizzaiolo Raffaele Esposito to create a pizza in honor of the visiting Queen Margherita. Of the three contenders he created, the Queen strongly preferred a pie swathed in the colors of the Italian flag — red (tomato), green (basil), and white (mozzarella).
column12: archivedate=July 12, 2009 }}</ref> According to the tale, this combination was named Pizza Margherita in her honor. Although those were the most preferred, today there are many variations of pizzas.

column5: accessdate=June 5, 2009}}</ref> (\"True Neapolitan Pizza Association\"), which was founded in 1984, has set the very specific rules that must be followed for an authentic Neapolitan pizza. These include that the pizza must be baked in a wood-fired, domed oven; that the base must be hand-kneaded and must not be rolled with a pin or prepared by any mechanical means (''i pizzaioli'' — the pizza makers — make the pizza by rolling it with their fingers) and that the pizza must not exceed 35 centimetres in diameter or be more than one-third of a centimetre thick at the centre. The association also selects pizzerias all around the world to produce and spread the verace pizza napoletana philosophy and method.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: There are many famous pizzerias in Naples where these traditional pizzas can be found such as Da Michele, Port'Alba, Brandi, Di Matteo, Sorbillo, Trianon, and Umberto. Most of them are in the ancient historical centre of Naples. These pizzerias follow even stricter standards than the specified rules by, for example, using only [[San Marzano tomato]]es grown on the slopes of [[Mount Vesuvius]] and drizzling the olive oil and adding tomato topping in only a clockwise direction.

The pizza bases in Naples are soft and pliable. In Rome they prefer a thin and crispy base. Another popular form of pizza in Italy is \"[[pizza al taglio]]\", which is pizza baked in rectangular trays with a wide variety of toppings and sold by weight.
In 1962, the \"Hawaiian\" pizza, a pizza topped with pineapple and ham, was invented in Canada by restaurateur Sam Panopoulis at the Satellite Restaurant in [[Chatham-Kent
column5: title=Meet the 81-Year-Old Greek-Canadian Inventor of the Hawaiian Pizza

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: [[Canada]]'s first pizzeria opened in 1948, Pizzeria Napoletana in [[Montreal]].<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=From the archives: Montreal pizzerias, the labour of doughy love
column5: publisher=montrealgazzette.com}}</ref> Starting in the late 1950s, the first pizza ovens started entering the country.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Bringing the first pizza ovens to Canada in the 1950s
column12: archivedate=March 18, 2016}}</ref> It gained popularity throughout the 1960s, with many pizzerias and restaurants opening across the country. Pizza was mostly served in restaurants and small [[List of pizza chains
column13: pizzerias]]. Most pizza restaurants across Canada also serve popular Italian cuisine in addition to pizza, such as pasta, salad, soups and sandwiches. Fast-food pizza chains also provide other side options for customers to choose from, in addition to ordering pizza, including chicken wings, fries and [[poutine]], salad, and [[calzone]]s. [[Pizza Pops]] are a Canadian calzone-type snack introduced in the 1960s. Pizza chains across Canada can be found in shopping centres, schools, and neighbourhood plazas, with the majority of these chains offering a sit-and-dine facility for customers.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The most distinct pizza in Canada is the \"Canadian\" pizza. A \"Canadian\" pizza is usually prepared with tomato sauce, mozzarella cheese, pepperoni, mushrooms, and bacon. Many variations of this pizza exist, but the two standout ingredients that make this pizza distinctly Canadian are bacon and mushrooms. Pizzas in Canada are almost never served with \"[[Canadian bacon]]\", or back bacon as it's referred to in Canada. Rather, side bacon is the standard pork topping on pizza.

In Canada, pizza is served on a variety of crust types, including a traditional-style pan crust, a thin crust, multi-grain crust, whole-grain crust, and a gluten-free crust. Stuffed-crust pizza is also a popular pizza alternative for Canadian customers. It contains pizza toppings of the customer's choice on a mozzarella-filled crust.

In the province of Quebec [[Pizza-ghetti]] is a combination meal commonly found in fast food or family restaurants. It consists of a pizza, sliced in half, accompanied by a small portion of spaghetti with a tomato based sauce. Although both pizza and spaghetti are considered staples of Italian cuisine, combining them in one dish is completely unknown in Italy. A popular variant involves using spaghetti as a pizza topping, under the pizza's mozzarella cheese

Some of Canada's successful pizza brands include: [[Boston Pizza]], [[Pizza Pizza]], and Vanelli's. Boston Pizza, also known as BP's in Canada, and \"Boston's—the Gourmet Pizza\" in the United States and Mexico, is one of Canada's largest franchising restaurants.<ref name=\"Boston Pizza Company History\">{{cite web
column8: archivedate=February 4, 2016}}</ref> The brand has opened over 325 locations across Canada and 50 locations in Mexico and the US.<ref name=\"Boston Pizza Company History\"/> The first Boston Pizza location was opened in Edmonton, Alberta, in 1964, and operated under the name \"Boston Pizza & Spaghetti House\", with locations still opening across the nation. It is the first Canadian restaurant to introduce the heart-shaped pizza on Valentine's Day, a 22-year tradition, where a dollar from each pizza ordered supports Boston Pizza Foundation Future Prospects.<ref>{{cite web

Mexican actress, singer and model}}: title=Boston Pizza Once Again Offering Heart Shaped Pizza For Valentine's Day
column5: accessdate=February 20, 2014}}</ref> Pizza Pizza, and its subsidiary chain [[Pizza 73]] in Western Canada, are among Canada's largest domestic brands based in Ontario.{{citation needed
column6: date=July 2014}} To date, they have over 500 locations nationwide, and fill more than 29 million orders annually.<ref>{{cite web

Mexican actress, singer and model}}: title=Hungry? Want Pizza? There's an app to help you order one

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Vanelli's is an international pizza chain that is based in [[Mississauga]].<ref name=\"About Us\">{{cite web
column6: accessdate=February 20, 2014}}</ref> The chain first opened in 1981, serving both pizza and other fresh Italian cuisine, such as pasta and Italian sandwiches.<ref name=\"About Us\"/> In 1995, the brand opened its first international location in [[Bahrain]] and became an international success. The brand continued to open additional locations across the Middle East, with chains now opened in the [[United Arab Emirates]], [[Lebanon]], and [[Morocco]].<ref>{{cite web
column11: accessdate=February 20, 2014}}</ref> There are over 110 locations worldwide; making Vanelli's the first pizza brand in Canada to open locations internationally.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: With pizza gaining popularity across the nation, major American pizza chains such as [[Pizza Hut]], [[Domino's Pizza]] and [[Little Caesars]] have expanded their locations in Canada, competing against the domestic Canadian brands. The major American pizza chains have brought their signature classic pizza recipes and toppings into their Canadian chains, offering their traditional classic pizzas to Canadian customers. However, the American chains have also created Canadian specialty pizzas that are available only in Canada.

column8: page=48}}</ref> and was popular among large Italian populations in [[New York City]], [[Chicago]], [[Philadelphia]], [[Trenton, New Jersey

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: According to a 2009 response published in a column on [[Serious Eats]], the first printed reference to \"pizza\" served in the US is a 1904 article in ''[[The Boston Journal]]''.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Dear Slice: Boston May Have Had the First Pizza in America
column9: accessdate=July 17, 2010}}</ref> Giovanni and Gennaro Bruno came to America from Naples, Italy, in 1903 and introduced the Neapolitan pizza to Boston. Later, Vincent Bruno (Giovanni's son) went on to open the first pizzeria in Chicago.<ref>{{cite news
column11: title=Readers weigh in on top Sheboygan, Manitowoc pizzerias

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Conflicting stories have the first pizzeria opening in 1905 when [[Gennaro Lombardi]] applied for a license in New York to make and sell pizza.  One of the generally accepted first US business to sell pizza, [[Lombardi's]], opened in 1897 as a grocery store at 53½ [[Spring Street (Manhattan)
column3: tomato pie]]s wrapped in paper and tied with a string at lunchtime to workers from the area's factories. In 1905, putative founder Gennaro Lombardi received a business license to operate a pizzeria restaurant, and soon had a clientele that included Italian tenor [[Enrico Caruso]]. He later passed the business on to his son, George.<ref name=inside>{{cite book
column9: title=Inside the Apple: A Streetwise History of New York City

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Pizza was brought to the [[Trenton, New Jersey
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Trenton]] area of [[New Jersey]] with Joe's Tomato Pies opening in 1910, followed soon by [[Papa's Tomato Pies]] in 1912. In 1936, [[De Lorenzo's Tomato Pies]] was opened. While Joe's Tomato Pies has closed, both Papa's and Delorenzo's have been run by the same families since their openings and remain among the most popular pizzas in the area. [[Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana]] in [[New Haven]], Connecticut, was another early pizzeria which opened in 1925 (after the owner served pies from local carts and bakeries for 20–25 years) and is famous for its New Haven–style Clam Pie. Frank Pepe's nephew Sal Consiglio opened a competing store, [[Sally's Apizza]], on the other end of the block, in 1938. Both establishments are still run by descendants of the original family. When Sal died, over 2,000 people attended his wake, and ''[[The New York Times]]'' ran a half-page memoriam. The D'Amore family introduced pizza to [[Los Angeles]] in 1939.

Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Italian Campaign]], who were introduced to [[Italian cuisine
column3: Italy's native cuisine]] proved a ready market for pizza in particular,<ref name=HTV>{{cite web
column6: title=A Slice of History: Pizza Through the Ages
column10: accessdate=November 9, 2014}}</ref> touted by \"veterans ranging from the lowliest private to [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]]\".<ref>{{Cite web

Leading early pizza chains were [[Shakey's Pizza]], founded in 1954 in [[Sacramento, California]]; [[Pizza Hut]], founded in 1958 in [[Wichita, Kansas]]; [[Little Caesars]], founded in 1959 in [[Garden City, Michigan]] and Josey's Pizza, founded in [[Newnan, Georgia]], in 1943.{{citation needed
column4: reason=Is there any evidence that Josey's was around to serve Pizza during WWII since America was at war with Italy at that time?}} Later restaurant chains in the dine-in pizza market were [[Bertucci's]], [[Happy Joe's]], [[Monical's Pizza]], [[California Pizza Kitchen]], [[Godfather's Pizza]], and [[Round Table Pizza]],<ref>{{cite web
column9: accessdate=August 10, 2013}}</ref> as well as Domino's, Pizza Hut, Little Caesars and Papa John's. Pizzas from [[take and bake pizzeria]]s, and chilled or frozen pizzas from supermarkets make pizza readily available nationwide. 13% of the US population consumes pizza on any given day.<ref>{{cite report

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: * An early reference to a pizza-like food occurs in the [[Aeneid]] (ca. 19 BC), when Celaeno, the [[Harpy]] queen, foretells that the Trojans would not find peace until they are forced by hunger to eat their tables (Book III). In Book VII, [[Aeneas]] and his men are served a meal that includes round cakes (like pita bread) topped with cooked vegetables. When they eat the bread, they realize that these are the \"tables\" prophesied by Celaeno.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Aeneas and Trojans fulfill Anchises' prophecy.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Foods similar to flatbreads in other parts of the world include Chinese [[Bing (bread)
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: bing]] (a wheat flour-based Chinese food with a flattened or disk-like shape); the Indian [[paratha]] (in which fat is incorporated); the Central and South Asian [[naan]] (leavened) and [[roti]] (unleavened); the Sardinian [[Pane carasau
column4: rieska]]. Also worth noting is that throughout Europe there are many similar pies based on the idea of covering flat pastry with cheese, meat, vegetables and seasoning such as the Alsatian [[flammkuchen]], German [[zwiebelkuchen]], and French [[quiche]].

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In 16th-century [[Naples]], a [[galette]] flatbread was referred to as a pizza. Known as the dish for poor people, it was sold in the street and was not considered a kitchen recipe for a long time.<ref>{{cite web
column8: archive-date=2012-12-19}}</ref> This was later replaced by oil, tomatoes (after Europeans came into contact with the Americas) or fish. In 1843, [[Alexandre Dumas]], described the diversity of pizza toppings.<ref name=dumas>{{cite book
column17: accessdate=May 22, 2012}}</ref> An often recounted story holds that on June 11, 1889, to honour the Queen consort of [[Italy]], [[Margherita of Savoy]], the [[Naples
column18: Neapolitan]] pizzamaker [[Raffaele Esposito]] created the \"[[Pizza Margherita]]\", a pizza garnished with tomatoes, [[mozzarella]], and basil, to represent the [[national colours of Italy]] as on the [[Flag of Italy]].<ref>{{cite journal
column32: title=Pizza purists out to protect patriotic pie
column35: date=March 2, 1989}}</ref><!-- p=12A --><!-- NOTE: American Heritage article by Hanna Miller is not a reliable citation for this claim -->

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Pizza evolved into a type of bread and tomato dish, often served with cheese. However, until the late 19th or early 20th century, the dish was sweet, not savory, and earlier versions which were savory more resembled the flat breads now known as [[schiacciata]].<ref>Alexandra Grigorieva,  \"Naming Authenticity and Regional Italian Cuisine [https://books.google.com/books?lr=lang_en&id=HflTVd898PAC&dq=Pellegrino+Artusi&q=pizza#v=snippet&q=pizza&f=false],\" in Richard Hosking, ed., ''Authenticity in the Kitchen: Proceedings of the Oxford Symposium on Food and Cookery 2005'' (Prospect Books, 2006): 211–216.</ref> [[Pellegrino Artusi]]'s classic early-twentieth-century cookbook, ''La Scienza in cucina e l'Arte di mangiar bene'' gives three recipes for pizza, all of which are sweet.<ref>Pellegrino Artusi, ''La scienza in cucina e l'Arte di mangiar bene'' (1911; rpr. Torino: Einaudi, 2001)</ref> After the feedback of some readers, Artusi added a typed sheet in the 1911 edition (discovered by food historian Alberto Capatti), bound with the volume, with the recipe of \"pizza alla napoletana\": mozzarella, tomatoes, anchovies and mushrooms.<ref>Mattozzi, Antonio e Donatella (2016)  \"Pizze, pizzerie e pizzaiuoli a Napoli tra Sette e Ottocento\" p.35, in ''Pizza. Una grande tradizione italiana''. Bra: Slow Food Publisher</ref>
However, by 1927, Ada Boni's collection of regional cooking includes a recipe using tomatoes and mozzarella.<ref>Grigorieva, Naming Authenticity,\" p. 211-212.</ref>

The innovation that led to flat bread pizza was the use of [[tomato]] as a topping. For some time after the tomato was brought to [[Europe]] from the Americas in the 16th century, it was believed by many Europeans to be poisonous, as some other fruits of the ''[[Solanaceae]]'' (nightshade) family are. However, by the late 18th century, it was common for the poor of the area around [[Naples]] to add tomato to their yeast-based flat bread, and so the pizza began.{{citation needed
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: date=November 2014}} The dish gained popularity, and soon pizza became a tourist attraction as visitors to Naples ventured into the poorer areas of the city to try the local specialty.

column4: [[Antica Pizzeria Port'Alba]] in Naples, which is widely believed to be the world's first pizzeria]]

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: According to documents discovered by historian Antonio Mattozzi in State Archive of Naples, in 1807 already 54 pizzerias existed, with their owners and addresses.<ref>Mattozzi, Antonio (2015) ''Inventing the'' ''Pizzeria: a History of Pizza Making in Naples'', Bloomsbury Academic, pp.16–17</ref> In the second half of the nineteenth century they increased to 120.<ref>Mattozzi, Antonio  ''Inventing the Pizzeria'', Distribution Maps, p.xxxiv</ref>

In Naples, two others figures connected to the trade existed — the pizza hawker (''pizzaiuolo ambulante''), who sold pizza, but did not make it, and the seller of pizza \"a oggi a otto\", who made pizzas, but sold them in return for a payment for seven days.<ref>Mattozzi, Antonio ''Inventing the Pizzeria'', p.28</ref>
The [[pizza marinara]] method has a topping of tomato, [[oregano]], [[garlic]], and [[Olive oil#Commercial grades
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: extra virgin olive oil]]. It is named \"marinara\" because it was traditionally the food prepared by \"la marinara\", the seaman's wife, for her seafaring husband when he returned from fishing trips in the [[Gulf of Naples

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The margherita is topped with modest amounts of tomato sauce, mozzarella and fresh basil. It is widely attributed to baker [[Raffaele Esposito]], who worked at restaurant \"Pietro... e basta così\" (\"Pietro... and that's enough\"), established in 1880 and still in business as \"Pizzeria Brandi\". Though recent research casts doubt on this legend,<ref>{{cite web

Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Umberto I]] and Queen [[Margherita of Savoy]]. The Queen's favorite was a pizza evoking the colors of the Italian flag — green ([[basil]] leaves), white ([[mozzarella]]), and red ([[tomato]]es).<ref name=amherit>{{cite news
column5: quote=Cheese, the crowning ingredient, was not added until 1889, when the Royal Palace commissioned the Neapolitan pizzaiolo Raffaele Esposito to create a pizza in honor of the visiting Queen Margherita. Of the three contenders he created, the Queen strongly preferred a pie swathed in the colors of the Italian flag — red (tomato), green (basil), and white (mozzarella).
column12: archivedate=July 12, 2009 }}</ref> According to the tale, this combination was named Pizza Margherita in her honor. Although those were the most preferred, today there are many variations of pizzas.

In the province of Quebec [[Pizza-ghetti]] is a combination meal commonly found in fast food or family restaurants. It consists of a pizza, sliced in half, accompanied by a small portion of spaghetti with a tomato based sauce. Although both pizza and spaghetti are considered staples of Italian cuisine, combining them in one dish is completely unknown in Italy. A popular variant involves using spaghetti as a pizza topping, under the pizza's mozzarella cheese

Some of Canada's successful pizza brands include: [[Boston Pizza]], [[Pizza Pizza]], and Vanelli's. Boston Pizza, also known as BP's in Canada, and \"Boston's—the Gourmet Pizza\" in the United States and Mexico, is one of Canada's largest franchising restaurants.<ref name=\"Boston Pizza Company History\">{{cite web
column8: archivedate=February 4, 2016}}</ref> The brand has opened over 325 locations across Canada and 50 locations in Mexico and the US.<ref name=\"Boston Pizza Company History\"/> The first Boston Pizza location was opened in Edmonton, Alberta, in 1964, and operated under the name \"Boston Pizza & Spaghetti House\", with locations still opening across the nation. It is the first Canadian restaurant to introduce the heart-shaped pizza on Valentine's Day, a 22-year tradition, where a dollar from each pizza ordered supports Boston Pizza Foundation Future Prospects.<ref>{{cite web

Mexican actress, singer and model}}: title=Boston Pizza Once Again Offering Heart Shaped Pizza For Valentine's Day
column5: accessdate=February 20, 2014}}</ref> Pizza Pizza, and its subsidiary chain [[Pizza 73]] in Western Canada, are among Canada's largest domestic brands based in Ontario.{{citation needed
column6: date=July 2014}} To date, they have over 500 locations nationwide, and fill more than 29 million orders annually.<ref>{{cite web

column6: accessdate=February 20, 2014}}</ref> The chain first opened in 1981, serving both pizza and other fresh Italian cuisine, such as pasta and Italian sandwiches.<ref name=\"About Us\"/> In 1995, the brand opened its first international location in [[Bahrain]] and became an international success. The brand continued to open additional locations across the Middle East, with chains now opened in the [[United Arab Emirates]], [[Lebanon]], and [[Morocco]].<ref>{{cite web
column11: accessdate=February 20, 2014}}</ref> There are over 110 locations worldwide; making Vanelli's the first pizza brand in Canada to open locations internationally.

However, the American chains have also created Canadian specialty pizzas that are available only in Canada.

One of the generally accepted first US business to sell pizza, [[Lombardi's]], opened in 1897 as a grocery store at 53½ [[Spring Street (Manhattan)
column3: tomato pie]]s wrapped in paper and tied with a string at lunchtime to workers from the area's factories. Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Pizza was brought to the [[Trenton, New Jersey
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Trenton]] area of [[New Jersey]] with Joe's Tomato Pies opening in 1910, followed soon by [[Papa's Tomato Pies]] in 1912. In 1936, [[De Lorenzo's Tomato Pies]] was opened. While Joe's Tomato Pies has closed, both Papa's and Delorenzo's have been run by the same families since their openings and remain among the most popular pizzas in the area. [[Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana]] in [[New Haven]], Connecticut, was another early pizzeria which opened in 1925 (after the owner served pies from local carts and bakeries for 20–25 years) and is famous for its New Haven–style Clam Pie. Frank Pepe's nephew Sal Consiglio opened a competing store, [[Sally's Apizza]], on the other end of the block, in 1938. Both establishments are still run by descendants of the original family. When Sal died, over 2,000 people attended his wake, and ''[[The New York Times]]'' ran a half-page memoriam. The D'Amore family introduced pizza to [[Los Angeles]] in 1939.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Twelve is the smallest [[abundant number]], since it is the smallest integer for which the sum of its proper divisors (1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 6 = 16) is greater than itself. Twelve is a [[sublime number]], a number that has a [[perfect number]] of divisors, and the sum of its divisors is also a perfect number.<ref>{{cite web
column4: website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences
column6: access-date=2016-06-01}}</ref> Since there is a subset of 12's proper divisors that add up to 12 (all of them but with 4 excluded), 12 is a [[semiperfect number]].<ref>{{Cite web
column9: website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences

*[[Wilhelm Heinrich Schüßler]] developed a list of 12 biochemical cell salts, also known as tissue salts.
