alt= The 1510 flu pandemic was the first to be chronicled across continents.
caption= The 1510 flu pandemic was the first to be chronicled across continents.
date= Early Summer to Fall of 1510

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In 1510 an acute respiratory disease emerged in Asia<ref name=\":1\" /><ref name=\":02\" /><ref name=\":14\" /> before spreading through [[North Africa]] and [[Europe]] during the first chronicled, inter-regional [[Influenza pandemic
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: flu pandemic]] generally recognized by medical historians and epidemiologists.<ref name=\":3\" /><ref name=\":02\" /><ref>{{Cite journal
column6: title=Introduction to Pandemic Influenza through History on
column31: title=THE BRITISH AND FOREIGN MEDICAL REVIEW OF QUARTERLY JOURNAL OF PRACTICAL MEDICINE AND SURGERY
column54: via=}}</ref><ref name=\":16\" /> Influenza-like illnesses had been documented in Europe since at least [[Charlemagne]],<ref name=\":02\" /> with 1357's outbreak the first to be called ''influenza'',<ref name=\":2\" /><ref name=\":10\" /> but the 1510 flu pandemic is the first to be pathologically described<ref>{{Cite book
column56: first=Clifford E. Trafzer, University of California
column58: title=Forgotten Voices: Death Records of the Yakama, 1888-1964
column69: title=Scientists explore 1510 influenza pandemic and lessons learned
column72: access-date=2020-03-25}}</ref> following communication advances brought about by the [[printing press]]. Flu became more widely referred to as ''coqueluche'' and ''coccolucio'' in [[Kingdom of France
column74: Sicily]] during this epidemic,<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite book
column85: language=fr}}</ref><ref name=\":11\" /> variations of which became the most popular names for flu in [[early modern Europe]].<ref name=\":02\" /> The pandemic caused significant disruption in government, church, and society<ref name=\":12\" /><ref name=\":14\" /><ref name=\"500th\" /> with near-universal infection<ref name=\":9\">{{Cite book
column89: title=Die Influenza. Ein historischer und ätiologischer Versuch ... Mit einer Vorrede von ... J. F. C. Hecker
column98: language=de}}</ref> and a mortality rate of around 1%.<ref name=\":02\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The 1510 flu is suspected of originating in East Asia,<ref name=\":02\" /> possibly [[China]].<ref name=\":1\" /> Gregor Horst asserts in ''Operum Medicorum tombs primus'' (1661) that the disease came from Asia and spread along trade routes<ref name=\":02\" /> before attacking the Middle East and North Africa. German medical writer [[Justus Hecker]] suggested the 1510 influenza most likely came from Asia because of the historical nature of other influenza viruses to originate there in more recent pandemics.<ref name=\":14\" />
[[File:Eastern Mediterranean and Aegean Sea. Battista Agnese, PORTOLAN ATLAS (Italy ca. 1550).jpg
column4: Influenza had spread in North Africa before arriving in Europe.]]

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The flu spread along trade routes towards North Africa,<ref name=\":02\" /> traveling southwest through the Middle East. Frequently visited cities like [[Jerusalem]] and [[Mecca]] would have almost certainly been reached by the flu, with large volumes of people destined to travel to [[Egypt]], North Africa, and the [[Ottoman Empire]].

It is generally understood that the 1510 influenza had spread in Africa before Europe.<ref name=\"catarrhal\" /><ref name=\":16\" /> Influenza was likely widespread in North Africa before crossing continents through the Mediterranean, arriving in [[Malta]]<ref name=\":3\" /><ref>{{Cite book
column12: language=en}} where British historian [[Thomas Vowler Short]] believes the \"island of ''Melite'' in ''Africa''\" became the 1510 flu's springboard into Europe.

column4: The disease came to Malta on crews infected in Africa.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Europe's internationally-traveled cities and flu's highly contagious nature enabled its spread through European populations. The 1510 flu disrupted royal courts, church services, and social life across Europe. Contemporary chroniclers and those who've read their accounts observed how entire populations were attacked at once,<ref name=\"catarrhal\" /><ref name=\":02\" /> which is how the disease first received the name ''influenza'' (from the belief that such outbreaks were caused by influences like stars or cold).<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite journal
column8: publisher=PG Department of Pharmacology, Govt Medical College, Srinagar
column11: via=ProQuest}}</ref> [[Turin]] professor Francisco Vallerioli (aka Valleriola) writes that the 1510 flu featured \"Constriction of breathing, and beginning with a hoarseness of voice and... shivering. Not long after that there being a cooked humor which fills the lungs.\"<ref name=\":02\" /> Physicians like Valleriola described the 1510 flu as more fatal to children<ref>{{Cite book
column22: language=en}}</ref> and those who were bled.<ref name=\"catarrhal\" />  Lawyer Francesco Muralto noted that \"the disease killed 10 people out of a thousand in one day,\" supporting a fatality rate of around 1%.<ref name=\":02\" />

column3: Flu arrived in Sicily from [[Malta]], and quickly spread along the Italian coast.]]

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The first cases of influenza began to appear in [[Sicily]] around July<ref name= Alibrandi>{{cite journal
column4: title=When early modern Europe caught the flu. A scientific account of pandemic influenza in sixteenth century Sicily
column7: pages=19-25}}</ref> after the arrival of infected merchant ships from [[Malta]].<ref name=\"catarrhal\" /><ref name=\":1\">{{Cite book
column11: title=Epidemiology; or, The remote cause of epidemic diseases in the animal and in the vegetable creation
column18: title=Dictionnaire encyclopédique des sciences médicales: publié sous la direction de MM. les docteurs Raige-Delorme et A. Dechambre
column20: publisher=P. Asselin, S' de Labé, V. Masson et fils
column25: language=fr}}</ref> In Sicily it was commonly called ''coccolucio'' for the hoods the sick often wore over their heads.<ref>{{Cite journal
column43: journal=History and Philosophy of the Life Sciences
column50: title=Annals of Influenza or Epidemic Catarrhal Fever in Great Britain
column57: accessdate=14 March 2020}}</ref> Influenza quickly spread out along the Mediterranean coasts of Italy and southern France<ref name=Alibrandi/> via merchant ships leaving the island.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In [[Emilia-Romagna]], Tommasino de' Bianchi recorded the recovery of [[Modena
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Modena's]] first cases on 13 July 1510, writing that in the city \"there appears an illness that lasts three days with a great fever, and headache and then they rise .. but there remains a terrible cough that lasts maybe eight days, and then they recover.\"<ref name=\":02\">{{Cite journal
column10: title=Eyewitness accounts of the 1510 influenza pandemic in Europe
column15: via=The Lancet}}</ref> This data would indicate that the first cases flu, which has an incubation period of one to four days, began to fall ill in the Emilia-Romagna region around late June or early July. In [[Bologna]] an 8 year-old named Ugo Bancopagni, who would later become [[Pope Gregory XIII]], became gravely ill with flu but recovered without permanent complications.<ref name=\":02\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: [[Pope Julius II]] attributed the outbreaks in [[Rome]] and the [[Holy See]] to God's wrath.<ref name=\":02\" /> [[Pope Gregory XIII]] would later blame the 1510 influenza in France on the resistance of [[Louis XII of France
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: King Louis XII]] to divine authority.<ref name=\":7\" />

column3: Achilles Gasser mentions an epidemic of \"catarrhal fever\" in upper Germany.<ref name=\":9\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Flu spread over the Alps into Switzerland and the [[Holy Roman Empire]]. In Switzerland it is documented as being called ''das Gruppie'' by the [[Mellingen]] chronicler Anton Tegenfeld,<ref>{{Cite book
column5: title=The Journal of English and German Philology
column10: pages=513}}</ref> the flu nickname then preferred by German-speaking Europeans. A respiratory illness seemed to have menaced the Canton of Aargua in June, with the population falling ill with sniffling, coughing, and fatigue.<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite book
column14: title=Grippe, Kamm und Eulenspiegel: Festschrift für Elmar Seebold zum 65. Geburtstag
column22: language=de}}</ref> German physician [[Achilles Gasser]] records a deadly epidemic spreading over the Holy Roman Empire's upper Kingdoms, branching into the cities and the \"whole mankind:\" ''Mira qua edam Epidemia mortales per urbes hanc totamque adeo superiorem Germaniam corripiebat, qua aegri IV vel V ad summum dies molestissimis destillationibus laborabant ac ration privati instar phrenicorum furebant, atque inde iterum convalescebant, paucissimis ad Gorcum demissis.''<ref name=\":9\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: André de Burgo's letters dated 24 August 1510 indicate [[Margaret of Austria, Duchess of Savoy
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Margaret of Austria]] had to intervene at a royal assembly between her father, [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor
column3: Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian I]], and [[Louis XII of France]] because the King of France was too sick with \"coqueluche\" to be spoken to.<ref name=\":6\">{{Cite book
column7: title=Lettres du roi Louis XII et du cardinal Georges d'Amboise: depuis 1504 à 1514
column15: language=fr}}</ref> Influenza spread out from the Holy Roman Empire towards Northern Europe, the [[Baltic states]],<ref name=\":11\" /> and west towards [[Kingdom of France

column3: It quickly spread to France's southern port cities first, then westward from the Alps to Paris.<ref name=\"catarrhal\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Arriving aboard infected sailors from Sicily, influenza struck the [[Kingdom of France]] through the ports of [[Marseille]] and [[Nice]] and spread through the international crowds of the shipyards. It was referred to as ''cephalie catarrhal'' or more commonly ''coqueluche''.<ref name=\":02\" /><ref name=\":0\" /><ref name=\":6\" /><ref name=\":7\" /><ref>{{Cite book
column5: title=Abhandlung über die Grippe (Influenza) in Wien in dem Jahre 1833
column16: title=Traite De La Coqueluche, d'apres les Principes de la Doctrine Physiologique
column23: Mézeray]] traces the etymology of ''coqueluche'' to the 1410s<ref name=\":5\" /> when sufferers would wear bonnets resembling coqueluchons, a kind of monk's cowl. <ref>{{Cite book
column27: title=Annalles et chronicques du pais de Laval et parties circonvoisines depuis l'an de Nostre Seigneur Ihesu-Crist 1480 jusqú à l'année 1537, avec un préambule retrospectif du temps anticque jadis
column34: language=fr}}</ref>French surgeon [[Ambroise Paré]] describes the outbreak as having been a \"rheumatic affliction of the head...with constriction of the heart and lungs.\"<ref name=\":02\" /> Merchants, pilgrims, and other travelers from the south and east spread the virus throughout the western Mediterranean in July.<ref name=\":4\" /> By August it had appeared in [[Tours]] and rapidly propagated itself throughout France, sickening the entire country by September.<ref name=\":5\">{{Cite book
column38: title=Annali delle epidemie occorse in Italia dalle prime memorie fino al 1850 scritti da Alfonso Corradi: Dal 1501 a tutto il 1600 con una tavola delle cose piu memorabili si della 1. che della 2. parte
column45: language=it}}</ref> French poet and historian Jean Bouchet, employed by King Louis XII's Royal Court, wrote that the epidemic \"appeared in the entire Kingdom of France, as much in the towns as in the countryside.\"<ref name=\":02\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: ''Coqueluche'' filled up the hospitals in France.<ref>{{Cite book
column10: pages=262}}</ref> King Louis XII's National Assembly of [[Bishop
column13: professors]] scheduled for September 1510 was delayed because of the intensity of the flu in [[Paris]]. <ref name=\"500th\" /> [[Jean Fernel]] (aka Fernelius), physician to [[Henry III of France]], compares the 1557 influenza to the 1510 epidemic which attacked everyone with fever, a heaviness in their head, and profound coughing.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite book
column17: title=Twentieth Century Practice: An International Encyclopedia of Modern Medical Science by Leading Authors of Europe and America
column25: pages=11}}</ref> Up to 1000 Parisians per day were dying at the height of the \"1510 peste.\"<ref>{{Cite book
column29: title=Quintessence de l'économie politique transcendante à l'usage des électeurs et des philosophes par le baron de Münster
column36: language=fr}}</ref> French historian [[François Eudes de Mézeray
column37: François Eudes de Mézery]] mentions that it disrupted judicial proceeding and colleges,<ref name=\":12\" /><ref name=\":14\" /> and that the 1510 flu was more widespread and deadly in France than in other countries.<ref>{{Cite book
column41: title=Des Caractèrs Généraux des Affections Catarrhals Aigues

column3: [[François Eudes de Mézeray]] had access to original documents describing the influenza of 1510.<ref name=\":02\" />]]

Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Cardinal Georges d'Amboise]], a close friend and advisor to the King of France, is sometimes believed to have died of influenza since his health sharply declined after arriving in Lyons in May 1510.<ref>{{Cite book
column6: title=The History of France: From the Earliest Period to the Present Time
column13: language=en}}</ref>  The cardinal, also known as Monseigneur le Ledat, made his final testimony and recited [[Sacraments of the Catholic Church
column18: title=Lettres du roi Louis XII et du cardinal Georges d'Amboise: depuis 1504 à 1514
column26: language=fr}}</ref> before he died on the 25. His sudden decline in health and flu's arrival in Europe around early summer have created uncertainty as to whether he died of gout or influenza, but \"coqueluche\" is not mentioned in French royal correspondence that year until August.<ref name=\":6\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: British medical historian [[Charles Creighton]] claims there is one foreign account of the 1510 flu in England,<ref name=\":11\">{{Cite book
column5: title=A History of Epidemics in Britain ...
column12: language=en}}</ref> but does not elaborate.<ref name=\":11\" /> An epidemiological study of past influenza pandemics reviewing previous medical historians has found England was affected in 1510.<ref>{{Cite book
column16: title=The American Journal of Hygiene: Monographic series
column25: Paré]] suggest that the 1510 influenza \"spread to almost all countries of the world, except the New World.\"<ref name=\":02\" /> There were reports of symptoms like \"gastrodynia\" and noteworthy murrain among cattle.<ref>{{Cite book
column36: language=en}}</ref> The 1510 flu is also recorded to have reached [[Ireland]].<ref name=\":15\" />

column4: Influenza spread to [[Spain]] and [[Portugal]] around the same time it reached the Alps.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Influenza reached the [[Iberian Peninsula]] early after Italy, due to the highly interconnected trade and pilgrimage routes between Spain, Portugal, and the Italian kingdoms. Cases began to appear in Portugal around the same time the disease entered the Holy Roman Empire.<ref name=\"catarrhal\" /> Spanish cities were reportedly \"dispopulated\" by the 1510 flu.<ref name=\":16\">{{Cite book
column5: title=Pandemic Influenza: Emergency Planning and Community Preparedness

column3: Influenza previously attacked the [[Island of Santo Domingo]] in 1493 with severe consequences.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: There are no records of influenza affecting the [[New World]] in 1510,<ref name=\":02\" /> even though numerous other European powers like France, England, and Portugal were sending their first fleets of ships to the [[New World]] after [[Spain]]. Influenza had previously afflicted the Isle of Santo Domingo (now [[Hispaniola]]) in [[1493]].<ref>{{Cite journal
column5: title=The Earliest American Epidemic: The Influenza of 1493

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Blistering on the back of the head and shoulders was one form of treatment prescribed in Europe for the flu.<ref name=\":02\" /> [[Ambroise Paré
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Paré]] regarded the common treatments of [[bloodletting]] and [[purgation]] to be especially dangerous to 1510's flu patients.<ref name=\":02\" /> Supraorbital pain and vision problems were symptoms<ref name=\":13\" /> of ''coqueluche'', so sufferers may have felt tempted to wear hoods due to light sensitivity. [[Thomas Vowler Short
column3: Short]] describes some medicinal treatments for the 1510 flu including \"Bole Armoniac, oily lintus, pectoral troches, and decoctions.\"<ref name=\"catarrhal\" />

Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Justus Hecker]] and John Parkin presume the 1510 influenza originated from East Asia because of the historical nature of other influenzas originating from said region,<ref name=\":14\">{{Cite book
column6: title=The epidemics of the middle ages
column19: title=An Epitome of the Reports of the Medical Officers to the Chinese Imperial Maritime Customs Service, from 1871 to 1882: With Chapters on the History of Medicine in China, Materia Medica, Epidemics, Famine, Ethnology, and Chronology in Relation to Medicine and Public Health
column26: language=en}}</ref> while Gregor Horst documented that the 1510 flu spread along trade routes from East Asia to Africa before reaching Europe in 1661.<ref name=\":02\" /> Influenza viruses sometimes leap from Asia's migratory water fowl after massive migrations congregate near water sources for humans and domesticated animals (which can function as a cross-species catalysts for creating new strains of pandemic flu).<ref>{{Cite journal
column34: title=The pig as a mixing vessel for influenza viruses: Human and veterinary implications
column36: journal=Journal of molecular and genetic medicine : an international journal of biomedical research
column44: title=The Origin of New Flu Strains
column47: access-date=2020-03-25}}</ref> European chroniclers noticed that the 1510 influenza did appear in North Africa before Europe, which has lead some medical historians to suggest it may have developed there<ref name=\":15\">{{Cite book
column51: title=Armies of Pestilence: The Impact of Disease on History
column58: language=en}}</ref>(parts of [[North Africa]] also lie along migratory bird ways, specifically the east Africa-West Asia and Black Sea-Mediterranean routes, that make it vulnerable to spontaneous reassortment of pandemic flu viruses).<ref>{{Cite journal
column64: title=Influenza: the role of the Middle East and north Africa?
column73: pmid=29695361}}</ref> But there remains no chronicled or biological evidence to suggest the 1510 flu originated from, as opposed to just spread in, Africa before reaching Europe.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The 1510 ''coqueluche'' has been recognized as influenza by modern epidemiologists<ref name=\"500th\" /><ref name=\":02\" /> and medical historians.<ref name=\":11\" /> Suggestions that the 1510 ''coqueluche'' was [[whooping cough]] have been doubted<ref name=\":8\">{{Cite book
column5: title=Whooping Cough: Essential Facts Concerning Whooping Cough, Its Prevention and Treatment with Appropriate Vaccines
column12: language=en}}</ref> because adult sufferers often experienced \"precipitous\"<ref name=\":02\" /> symptoms described by contemporaries like Thomasino de Bianchi<ref name=\":02\" /> or Valleriola as high fever for 3 days, headache, prostration, loss of sleep and appetite, delirium,<ref name=\":7\" /> a cough most severe on the 5th to 10th days, <ref name=\":12\">{{Cite book
column16: title=Encyclopedia of Practical Medicine: Variolla, Vaccination, Vericella, Cholera, Erysipelas, Whooping Cough, Hay Fever
column29: title=Paris Epidemics of the XVI Century
column31: journal=Medical Record: A Weekly Journal of Medicine and Surgery
column35: via=}}</ref> lung congestion,<ref name=\":02\" /> and slow recovery beginning on the second week.<ref name=\"catarrhal\" /><ref name=\":14\" />Adults with pertussis will usually cough for weeks before becoming gradually more ill then recovering over a period of months.<ref>{{Cite web
column44: title=American Association for the Study and Prevention of Infant Mortality: Transactions of the Annual Meeting - Milwaukee, October 19-21, 1916
column50: language=en}}</ref> The ''coqueluche'' of 1510 is considered to be influenza by most experts, from modern epidemiologists<ref name=\":02\" /><ref name=\"500th\" /> to medical historians<ref name=\":11\" /> due to its sudden onset of symptoms, explosive spread over Europe,<ref name=\":10\" /> and timelines of sickness to recovery. The first outbreak of whooping cough to be agreed on by most medical historians is [[Guillaume de Baillou
column51: Guillaume de Baillou's]] description of an outbreak in Paris in [[1578]].<ref name=\":8\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: [[Category:Epidemics]]","[[File:1500 map by Juan de la Cosa-North up.jpg
column4: The 1510 flu pandemic was the first to be chronicled across continents.]]

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In 1510 an acute respiratory disease emerged in Asia<ref name=\":1\" /><ref name=\":02\" /><ref name=\":14\" /> before spreading through [[North Africa]] and [[Europe]] during the first chronicled, inter-regional [[Influenza pandemic
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: flu pandemic]] generally recognized by medical historians and epidemiologists.<ref name=\":3\" /><ref name=\":02\" /><ref>{{Cite journal
column6: title=Introduction to Pandemic Influenza through History on
column31: title=THE BRITISH AND FOREIGN MEDICAL REVIEW OF QUARTERLY JOURNAL OF PRACTICAL MEDICINE AND SURGERY
column54: via=}}</ref><ref name=\":16\" /> Influenza-like illnesses had been documented in Europe since at least [[Charlemagne]],<ref name=\":02\" /> with 1357's outbreak the first to be called ''influenza'',<ref name=\":2\" /><ref name=\":10\" /> but the 1510 flu pandemic is the first to be pathologically described<ref>{{Cite book
column56: first=Clifford E. Trafzer, University of California
column58: title=Forgotten Voices: Death Records of the Yakama, 1888-1964
column69: title=Scientists explore 1510 influenza pandemic and lessons learned
column72: access-date=2020-03-25}}</ref> following communication advances brought about by the [[printing press]]. Flu became more widely referred to as ''coqueluche'' and ''coccolucio'' in [[Kingdom of France
column74: Sicily]] during this epidemic,<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite book
column85: language=fr}}</ref><ref name=\":11\" /> variations of which became the most popular names for flu in [[early modern Europe]].<ref name=\":02\" /> The pandemic caused significant disruption in government, church, and society<ref name=\":12\" /><ref name=\":14\" /><ref name=\"500th\" /> with near-universal infection<ref name=\":9\">{{Cite book
column89: title=Die Influenza. Ein historischer und ätiologischer Versuch ... Mit einer Vorrede von ... J. F. C. Hecker
column98: language=de}}</ref> and a mortality rate of around 1%.<ref name=\":02\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The 1510 flu is suspected of originating in East Asia,<ref name=\":02\" /> possibly [[China]].<ref name=\":1\" /> Gregor Horst asserts in ''Operum Medicorum tombs primus'' (1661) that the disease came from Asia and spread along trade routes<ref name=\":02\" /> before attacking the Middle East and North Africa. German medical writer [[Justus Hecker]] suggested the 1510 influenza most likely came from Asia because of the historical nature of other influenza viruses to originate there in more recent pandemics.<ref name=\":14\" />
[[File:Eastern Mediterranean and Aegean Sea. Battista Agnese, PORTOLAN ATLAS (Italy ca. 1550).jpg
column4: Influenza had spread in North Africa before arriving in Europe.]]

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The flu spread along trade routes towards North Africa,<ref name=\":02\" /> traveling southwest through the Middle East. Frequently visited cities like [[Jerusalem]] and [[Mecca]] would have almost certainly been reached by the flu, with large volumes of people destined to travel to [[Egypt]], North Africa, and the [[Ottoman Empire]].

It is generally understood that the 1510 influenza had spread in Africa before Europe.<ref name=\"catarrhal\" /><ref name=\":16\" /> Influenza was likely widespread in North Africa before crossing continents through the Mediterranean, arriving in [[Malta]]<ref name=\":3\" /><ref>{{Cite book
column12: language=en}} where British historian [[Thomas Vowler Short]] believes the \"island of ''Melite'' in ''Africa''\" became the 1510 flu's springboard into Europe.

column4: The disease came to Malta on crews infected in Africa.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Europe's internationally-traveled cities and flu's highly contagious nature enabled its spread through European populations. The 1510 flu disrupted royal courts, church services, and social life across Europe. Contemporary chroniclers and those who've read their accounts observed how entire populations were attacked at once,<ref name=\"catarrhal\" /><ref name=\":02\" /> which is how the disease first received the name ''influenza'' (from the belief that such outbreaks were caused by influences like stars or cold).<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite journal
column8: publisher=PG Department of Pharmacology, Govt Medical College, Srinagar
column11: via=ProQuest}}</ref> [[Turin]] professor Francisco Vallerioli (aka Valleriola) writes that the 1510 flu featured \"Constriction of breathing, and beginning with a hoarseness of voice and... shivering. Not long after that there being a cooked humor which fills the lungs.\"<ref name=\":02\" /> Physicians like Valleriola described the 1510 flu as more fatal to children<ref>{{Cite book
column22: language=en}}</ref> and those who were bled.<ref name=\"catarrhal\" />  Lawyer Francesco Muralto noted that \"the disease killed 10 people out of a thousand in one day,\" supporting a fatality rate of around 1%.<ref name=\":02\" />

column3: Flu arrived in Sicily from [[Malta]], and quickly spread along the Italian coast.]]

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The first cases of influenza began to appear in [[Sicily]] around July<ref name= Alibrandi>{{cite journal
column4: title=When early modern Europe caught the flu. A scientific account of pandemic influenza in sixteenth century Sicily
column7: pages=19-25}}</ref> after the arrival of infected merchant ships from [[Malta]].<ref name=\"catarrhal\" /><ref name=\":1\">{{Cite book
column11: title=Epidemiology; or, The remote cause of epidemic diseases in the animal and in the vegetable creation
column18: title=Dictionnaire encyclopédique des sciences médicales: publié sous la direction de MM. les docteurs Raige-Delorme et A. Dechambre
column20: publisher=P. Asselin, S' de Labé, V. Masson et fils
column25: language=fr}}</ref> In Sicily it was commonly called ''coccolucio'' for the hoods the sick often wore over their heads.<ref>{{Cite journal
column43: journal=History and Philosophy of the Life Sciences
column50: title=Annals of Influenza or Epidemic Catarrhal Fever in Great Britain
column57: accessdate=14 March 2020}}</ref> Influenza quickly spread out along the Mediterranean coasts of Italy and southern France<ref name=Alibrandi/> via merchant ships leaving the island.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In [[Emilia-Romagna]], Tommasino de' Bianchi recorded the recovery of [[Modena
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Modena's]] first cases on 13 July 1510, writing that in the city \"there appears an illness that lasts three days with a great fever, and headache and then they rise .. but there remains a terrible cough that lasts maybe eight days, and then they recover.\"<ref name=\":02\">{{Cite journal
column10: title=Eyewitness accounts of the 1510 influenza pandemic in Europe
column15: via=The Lancet}}</ref> This data would indicate that the first cases flu, which has an incubation period of one to four days, began to fall ill in the Emilia-Romagna region around late June or early July. In [[Bologna]] an 8 year-old named Ugo Bancopagni, who would later become [[Pope Gregory XIII]], became gravely ill with flu but recovered without permanent complications.<ref name=\":02\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: [[Pope Julius II]] attributed the outbreaks in [[Rome]] and the [[Holy See]] to God's wrath.<ref name=\":02\" /> [[Pope Gregory XIII]] would later blame the 1510 influenza in France on the resistance of [[Louis XII of France
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: King Louis XII]] to divine authority.<ref name=\":7\" />

column3: Achilles Gasser mentions an epidemic of \"catarrhal fever\" in upper Germany.<ref name=\":9\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Flu spread over the Alps into Switzerland and the [[Holy Roman Empire]]. In Switzerland it is documented as being called ''das Gruppie'' by the [[Mellingen]] chronicler Anton Tegenfeld,<ref>{{Cite book
column5: title=The Journal of English and German Philology
column10: pages=513}}</ref> the flu nickname then preferred by German-speaking Europeans. A respiratory illness seemed to have menaced the Canton of Aargua in June, with the population falling ill with sniffling, coughing, and fatigue.<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite book
column14: title=Grippe, Kamm und Eulenspiegel: Festschrift für Elmar Seebold zum 65. Geburtstag
column22: language=de}}</ref> German physician [[Achilles Gasser]] records a deadly epidemic spreading over the Holy Roman Empire's upper Kingdoms, branching into the cities and the \"whole mankind:\" ''Mira qua edam Epidemia mortales per urbes hanc totamque adeo superiorem Germaniam corripiebat, qua aegri IV vel V ad summum dies molestissimis destillationibus laborabant ac ration privati instar phrenicorum furebant, atque inde iterum convalescebant, paucissimis ad Gorcum demissis.''<ref name=\":9\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: André de Burgo's letters dated 24 August 1510 indicate [[Margaret of Austria, Duchess of Savoy
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Margaret of Austria]] had to intervene at a royal assembly between her father, [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor
column3: Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian I]], and [[Louis XII of France]] because the King of France was too sick with \"coqueluche\" to be spoken to.<ref name=\":6\">{{Cite book
column7: title=Lettres du roi Louis XII et du cardinal Georges d'Amboise: depuis 1504 à 1514
column15: language=fr}}</ref> Influenza spread out from the Holy Roman Empire towards Northern Europe, the [[Baltic states]],<ref name=\":11\" /> and west towards [[Kingdom of France

column3: It quickly spread to France's southern port cities first, then westward from the Alps to Paris.<ref name=\"catarrhal\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Arriving aboard infected sailors from Sicily, influenza struck the [[Kingdom of France]] through the ports of [[Marseille]] and [[Nice]] and spread through the international crowds of the shipyards. It was referred to as ''cephalie catarrhal'' or more commonly ''coqueluche''.<ref name=\":02\" /><ref name=\":0\" /><ref name=\":6\" /><ref name=\":7\" /><ref>{{Cite book
column5: title=Abhandlung über die Grippe (Influenza) in Wien in dem Jahre 1833
column16: title=Traite De La Coqueluche, d'apres les Principes de la Doctrine Physiologique
column23: Mézeray]] traces the etymology of ''coqueluche'' to the 1410s<ref name=\":5\" /> when sufferers would wear bonnets resembling coqueluchons, a kind of monk's cowl. <ref>{{Cite book
column27: title=Annalles et chronicques du pais de Laval et parties circonvoisines depuis l'an de Nostre Seigneur Ihesu-Crist 1480 jusqú à l'année 1537, avec un préambule retrospectif du temps anticque jadis
column34: language=fr}}</ref>French surgeon [[Ambroise Paré]] describes the outbreak as having been a \"rheumatic affliction of the head...with constriction of the heart and lungs.\"<ref name=\":02\" /> Merchants, pilgrims, and other travelers from the south and east spread the virus throughout the western Mediterranean in July.<ref name=\":4\" /> By August it had appeared in [[Tours]] and rapidly propagated itself throughout France, sickening the entire country by September.<ref name=\":5\">{{Cite book
column38: title=Annali delle epidemie occorse in Italia dalle prime memorie fino al 1850 scritti da Alfonso Corradi: Dal 1501 a tutto il 1600 con una tavola delle cose piu memorabili si della 1. che della 2. parte
column45: language=it}}</ref> French poet and historian Jean Bouchet, employed by King Louis XII's Royal Court, wrote that the epidemic \"appeared in the entire Kingdom of France, as much in the towns as in the countryside.\"<ref name=\":02\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: ''Coqueluche'' filled up the hospitals in France.<ref>{{Cite book
column10: pages=262}}</ref> King Louis XII's National Assembly of [[Bishop
column13: professors]] scheduled for September 1510 was delayed because of the intensity of the flu in [[Paris]]. <ref name=\"500th\" /> [[Jean Fernel]] (aka Fernelius), physician to [[Henry III of France]], compares the 1557 influenza to the 1510 epidemic which attacked everyone with fever, a heaviness in their head, and profound coughing.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite book
column17: title=Twentieth Century Practice: An International Encyclopedia of Modern Medical Science by Leading Authors of Europe and America
column25: pages=11}}</ref> Up to 1000 Parisians per day were dying at the height of the \"1510 peste.\"<ref>{{Cite book
column29: title=Quintessence de l'économie politique transcendante à l'usage des électeurs et des philosophes par le baron de Münster
column36: language=fr}}</ref> French historian [[François Eudes de Mézeray
column37: François Eudes de Mézery]] mentions that it disrupted judicial proceeding and colleges,<ref name=\":12\" /><ref name=\":14\" /> and that the 1510 flu was more widespread and deadly in France than in other countries.<ref>{{Cite book
column41: title=Des Caractèrs Généraux des Affections Catarrhals Aigues

column3: [[François Eudes de Mézeray]] had access to original documents describing the influenza of 1510.<ref name=\":02\" />]]

Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Cardinal Georges d'Amboise]], a close friend and advisor to the King of France, is sometimes believed to have died of influenza since his health sharply declined after arriving in Lyons in May 1510.<ref>{{Cite book
column6: title=The History of France: From the Earliest Period to the Present Time
column13: language=en}}</ref>  The cardinal, also known as Monseigneur le Ledat, made his final testimony and recited [[Sacraments of the Catholic Church
column18: title=Lettres du roi Louis XII et du cardinal Georges d'Amboise: depuis 1504 à 1514
column26: language=fr}}</ref> before he died on the 25. His sudden decline in health and flu's arrival in Europe around early summer have created uncertainty as to whether he died of gout or influenza, but \"coqueluche\" is not mentioned in French royal correspondence that year until August.<ref name=\":6\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: British medical historian [[Charles Creighton]] claims there is one foreign account of the 1510 flu in England,<ref name=\":11\">{{Cite book
column5: title=A History of Epidemics in Britain ...
column12: language=en}}</ref> but does not elaborate.<ref name=\":11\" /> An epidemiological study of past influenza pandemics reviewing previous medical historians has found England was affected in 1510.<ref>{{Cite book
column16: title=The American Journal of Hygiene: Monographic series
column25: Paré]] suggest that the 1510 influenza \"spread to almost all countries of the world, except the New World.\"<ref name=\":02\" /> There were reports of symptoms like \"gastrodynia\" and noteworthy murrain among cattle.<ref>{{Cite book
column36: language=en}}</ref> The 1510 flu is also recorded to have reached [[Ireland]].<ref name=\":15\" />

column4: Influenza spread to [[Spain]] and [[Portugal]] around the same time it reached the Alps.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Influenza reached the [[Iberian Peninsula]] early after Italy, due to the highly interconnected trade and pilgrimage routes between Spain, Portugal, and the Italian kingdoms. Cases began to appear in Portugal around the same time the disease entered the Holy Roman Empire.<ref name=\"catarrhal\" /> Spanish cities were reportedly \"dispopulated\" by the 1510 flu.<ref name=\":16\">{{Cite book
column5: title=Pandemic Influenza: Emergency Planning and Community Preparedness

column3: Influenza previously attacked the [[Island of Santo Domingo]] in 1493 with severe consequences.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: There are no records of influenza affecting the [[New World]] in 1510,<ref name=\":02\" /> even though numerous other European powers like France, England, and Portugal were sending their first fleets of ships to the [[New World]] after [[Spain]]. Influenza had previously afflicted the Isle of Santo Domingo (now [[Hispaniola]]) in [[1493]].<ref>{{Cite journal
column5: title=The Earliest American Epidemic: The Influenza of 1493

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Blistering on the back of the head and shoulders was one form of treatment prescribed in Europe for the flu.<ref name=\":02\" /> [[Ambroise Paré
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Paré]] regarded the common treatments of [[bloodletting]] and [[purgation]] to be especially dangerous to 1510's flu patients.<ref name=\":02\" /> Supraorbital pain and vision problems were symptoms<ref name=\":13\" /> of ''coqueluche'', so sufferers may have felt tempted to wear hoods due to light sensitivity. [[Thomas Vowler Short
column3: Short]] describes some medicinal treatments for the 1510 flu including \"Bole Armoniac, oily lintus, pectoral troches, and decoctions.\"<ref name=\"catarrhal\" />

Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Justus Hecker]] and John Parkin presume the 1510 influenza originated from East Asia because of the historical nature of other influenzas originating from said region,<ref name=\":14\">{{Cite book
column6: title=The epidemics of the middle ages
column19: title=An Epitome of the Reports of the Medical Officers to the Chinese Imperial Maritime Customs Service, from 1871 to 1882: With Chapters on the History of Medicine in China, Materia Medica, Epidemics, Famine, Ethnology, and Chronology in Relation to Medicine and Public Health
column26: language=en}}</ref> while Gregor Horst documented that the 1510 flu spread along trade routes from East Asia to Africa before reaching Europe in 1661.<ref name=\":02\" /> Influenza viruses sometimes leap from Asia's migratory water fowl after massive migrations congregate near water sources for humans and domesticated animals (which can function as a cross-species catalysts for creating new strains of pandemic flu).<ref>{{Cite journal
column34: title=The pig as a mixing vessel for influenza viruses: Human and veterinary implications
column36: journal=Journal of molecular and genetic medicine : an international journal of biomedical research
column44: title=The Origin of New Flu Strains
column47: access-date=2020-03-25}}</ref> European chroniclers noticed that the 1510 influenza did appear in North Africa before Europe, which has lead some medical historians to suggest it may have developed there<ref name=\":15\">{{Cite book
column51: title=Armies of Pestilence: The Impact of Disease on History
column58: language=en}}</ref>(parts of [[North Africa]] also lie along migratory bird ways, specifically the east Africa-West Asia and Black Sea-Mediterranean routes, that make it vulnerable to spontaneous reassortment of pandemic flu viruses).<ref>{{Cite journal
column64: title=Influenza: the role of the Middle East and north Africa?
column73: pmid=29695361}}</ref> But there remains no chronicled or biological evidence to suggest the 1510 flu originated from, as opposed to just spread in, Africa before reaching Europe.

Freeport is home to the mini-Wrigley replica, Little Cubs Field. The field is open or can be reserved for private gatherings such as tournaments, family reunions, or other events.]]

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: '''Freeport''' is the [[county seat]] and largest city of [[Stephenson County, Illinois
column9: archivedate=2014-05-19}}</ref> The population was 25,638 at the [[2010 United States Census
column10: 2010 census]], and the mayor of Freeport is Jodi Miller, elected in 2017. Freeport is known for hosting the second [[Lincoln–Douglas debates
column11: Lincoln-Douglas debate of 1858]], and as \"Pretzel City, USA\", due to a popular local German bakery known for its pretzels in the 1850s. [[Freeport High School (Illinois)
column12: Freeport High School]]'s mascot is the Pretzel to honor this unique heritage.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The community was originally called '''Winneshiek'''.<ref>{{cite book
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: author=Chicago and North Western Railway Company
column3: title=A History of the Origin of the Place Names Connected with the Chicago & North Western and Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis & Omaha Railways
column6: page=74}}</ref> When it was incorporated, the new municipality took its name from the generosity of [[Tutty Baker]], who was credited with running a \"free port\" on the [[Pecatonica River]]. The name \"Winneshiek\" was later adopted, and is preserved to this day, by the Freeport Community Theatre Group.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In 1837, Stephenson County was formed and Freeport became its seat of government in 1838. Linked by a stagecoach with [[Chicago]], the community grew rapidly. In 1840, a frame courthouse was erected and the first school was founded. Within two years, Freeport had two newspapers and in 1853, the two were joined by a third which published in German. By then, the community had a population of 2,000.

Mexican actress, singer and model}}: second debate]] between [[Abraham Lincoln]] and [[Stephen A. Douglas]] took place in Freeport and gave the nation direction in the following years. Although Stephen Douglas won the election and retained his [[U.S. Senate]] seat, his reply to a question on slavery alienated the South, which called it the \"[[Freeport Doctrine
column3: Freeport Heresy]]\", and split the [[Democratic Party (United States)
column4: Democratic Party]].<ref>Guelzom A. (2008). ''Lincoln and Douglas: The Debates that Defined America'', page 162. Simon & Schuster {{ISBN
column5: 0-7432-7320-6}}</ref> This enabled Abraham Lincoln to win the Presidency in 1860.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: A monument to the debate was dedicated in 1903 by President [[Theodore Roosevelt]] and stands at this site. A life size statue recreating the event was dedicated in 1992. Another renowned statue, ''Lincoln the Debator'' by [[Leonard Crunelle]], is a focal point in the city's Taylor Park. In many years there is also a reenactment of the debate, [[The Lincoln-Douglas Debates (1994 reenactments)

Freeport is known as the \"Pretzel City\", and its public high school's team is named the Pretzels.  The nickname is a reminder of Freeport's ethnic heritage; in the late 1850s, many [[German-American
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Germans]], both from Pennsylvania and from their European homeland, resettled in Stephenson County bringing with them their love of pretzel snacks.<ref>http://www.illinois.com/details/city.php?cityFips=1727884  {{webarchive
column4: date=September 30, 2011 }}</ref> In 1869, a German immigrant named John Billerbeck<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=John Billerbeck (1835-1899) » Stamboom familie Eilders » Genealogie Online
column9: accessdate=September 27, 2015}}</ref> established the Billerbeck Bakery, which distributed so many pretzels to residents that the local newspaper later dubbed Freeport the \"Pretzel City\". The city later capitalized on this nickname in 2003 by starting Freeport's first Pretzel Festival.<ref>{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Freeport is home to the oldest [[Carnegie Library]] in Illinois<ref>{{cite web
column4: publisher=}}</ref> and one of the first Carnegie Libraries designed by the [[Chicago]] architectural firm of Patton and Miller.  It was renovated into Freeport's City Hall <ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Freeport Carnegie Library-City Hall renovations on schedule
column11: archivedate=2017-03-15}}</ref> and City offices were moved to Carnegie City Hall in February 2017.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The City of Freeport transitioned to the City Manager Form of Government in May 2017. The first City Manager is Lowell Crow.
Before February 1893, a large square of land was purchased from the former Keller-Wittbecker farm in East Freeport.  Some of this land had recently{{When
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: date=September 2015}} been subdivided and platted as the \"Arcade Addition\".<ref>Reference to the ebook History of Stephenson County Illinois, Arcade Manufacturing Company, [http://www.ebooksread.com/authors-eng/addison-l-fulwider/history-of-stephenson-county-illinois--a-record-of-its-settlement-organizatio-wlu/page-64-history-of-stephenson-county-illinois--a-record-of-its-settlement-organizatio-wlu.shtml page 510] {{webarchive
column4: date=2014-08-13 }}.</ref> The Arcade Manufacturing Company had been in operation since 1885 when the previous [[Novelty Iron Works]] had gone out of business at the corner of Chicago and Jackson streets.  That earlier company began as early as 1868.  After the 1892 fire, the Arcade Manufacturing Company built an entirely new factory in the Arcade Addition of East Freeport, where they produced coffee mills and other metal products.

column3: title=Neighborhoods Face Extinction As Floods Increase

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The frequency of severe weather events appears to be increasing. According to the State Climatologist, \"the number of days Freeport has experienced heavy rainfall has steadily increased every decade since 1949.\"<ref name=\":0\" /> The city is seeking funding to buy out homes in flood-prone neighborhoods. One study estimates that for \"every $1 communities like Freeport spend to relocate their residents they will save $6 in future clean ups.\"<ref name=\":0\" />

title=Census of Population and Housing - U.S. Census Bureau

column5: title=U.S. Census website }}</ref> of 2000, there were 26,443 people, 11,222 households, and 6,845 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 2,316.9 people per square mile (894.8/km²). There were 12,471 housing units at an average density of 1,092.7/sq mi (422.0/km²). The racial makeup of the city was 81.77% [[White (U.S. Census)
column11: other races]], and 2.22% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)
column13: Latino]] of any race were 2.12% of the population.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: There were 11,222 households out of which 28.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 45.1% were [[Marriage
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: married couples]] living together, 12.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 39.0% were non-families. 33.7% of all households were made up of individuals and 15.1% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.29 and the average family size was 2.93.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In the city, the population was spread out with 24.5% under the age of 18, 8.5% from 18 to 24, 27.8% from 25 to 44, 21.2% from 45 to 64, and 18.1% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females, there were 87.1 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 83.8 males.

The median income for a household in the city was $35,399, and the median income for a family was $43,787. Males had a median income of $35,870 versus $25,095 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $18,680. About 9.9% of families and 13.1% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 18.6% of those under age 18 and 9.5% of those age 65 or over.

column3: date=March 14, 2012 }}</ref> Heavily wooded Krape Park features a waterfall that tumbles down from a high limestone bluff. Visitors can ride paddle boats, play mini golf, disc golf, or play on one of the three playground areas.

column5: adj=on}} park presented by the heirs of Orlando B. Bidwell, features a small shelter with restrooms, a softball field, and a playground.

adj=on}} park presented by the descendants of Dexter A. Knowlton to mark the 100th anniversary of his arrival to Freeport, features a bronze tablet and tall black maple trees to shade benches and play equipment.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: * Read Park features the Read Park Family Aquatic Center and a skate park. One of the larger parks in Freeport, it also features a large pavilion, basketball courts, children's playground, shuffleboard courts, tennis courts, and softball fields. It is also home to the newly added Little Cubs Field.

column4: km2}} of forests, streams and restored prairies including more than four miles (6 km) of trails as well as a 1/3-mile hard-packed accessible trail. It includes a lodge, an auditorium and a nature center.

column5: adj=on}} park acquired in 1911, features three lighted softball fields, concession stand, basketball courts, picnic shelter and Abraham Lincoln statue. This statue, located in the southwest section of the park, was sculpted in 1928–29 by Leonard Crunelle. Its dedication on August 27, 1929, was attended by many notable guests, and was covered by newspapers across the country.{{Citation needed

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: '''Freeport''' is the [[county seat]] and largest city of [[Stephenson County, Illinois
column9: archivedate=2014-05-19}}</ref> The population was 25,638 at the [[2010 United States Census
column10: 2010 census]], and the mayor of Freeport is Jodi Miller, elected in 2017. Freeport is known for hosting the second [[Lincoln–Douglas debates
column11: Lincoln-Douglas debate of 1858]], and as \"Pretzel City, USA\", due to a popular local German bakery known for its pretzels in the 1850s. [[Freeport High School (Illinois)
column12: Freeport High School]]'s mascot is the Pretzel to honor this unique heritage.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The community was originally called '''Winneshiek'''.<ref>{{cite book
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: author=Chicago and North Western Railway Company
column3: title=A History of the Origin of the Place Names Connected with the Chicago & North Western and Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis & Omaha Railways
column6: page=74}}</ref> When it was incorporated, the new municipality took its name from the generosity of [[Tutty Baker]], who was credited with running a \"free port\" on the [[Pecatonica River]]. The name \"Winneshiek\" was later adopted, and is preserved to this day, by the Freeport Community Theatre Group.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In 1837, Stephenson County was formed and Freeport became its seat of government in 1838. Linked by a stagecoach with [[Chicago]], the community grew rapidly. In 1840, a frame courthouse was erected and the first school was founded. Within two years, Freeport had two newspapers and in 1853, the two were joined by a third which published in German. By then, the community had a population of 2,000.

Mexican actress, singer and model}}: second debate]] between [[Abraham Lincoln]] and [[Stephen A. Douglas]] took place in Freeport and gave the nation direction in the following years. Although Stephen Douglas won the election and retained his [[U.S. Senate]] seat, his reply to a question on slavery alienated the South, which called it the \"[[Freeport Doctrine
column3: Freeport Heresy]]\", and split the [[Democratic Party (United States)
column4: Democratic Party]].<ref>Guelzom A. (2008). ''Lincoln and Douglas: The Debates that Defined America'', page 162. Simon & Schuster {{ISBN
column5: 0-7432-7320-6}}</ref> This enabled Abraham Lincoln to win the Presidency in 1860.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: A monument to the debate was dedicated in 1903 by President [[Theodore Roosevelt]] and stands at this site. A life size statue recreating the event was dedicated in 1992. Another renowned statue, ''Lincoln the Debator'' by [[Leonard Crunelle]], is a focal point in the city's Taylor Park. In many years there is also a reenactment of the debate, [[The Lincoln-Douglas Debates (1994 reenactments)

Freeport is known as the \"Pretzel City\", and its public high school's team is named the Pretzels.  The nickname is a reminder of Freeport's ethnic heritage; in the late 1850s, many [[German-American
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Germans]], both from Pennsylvania and from their European homeland, resettled in Stephenson County bringing with them their love of pretzel snacks.<ref>http://www.illinois.com/details/city.php?cityFips=1727884  {{webarchive
column4: date=September 30, 2011 }}</ref> In 1869, a German immigrant named John Billerbeck<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=John Billerbeck (1835-1899) » Stamboom familie Eilders » Genealogie Online
column9: accessdate=September 27, 2015}}</ref> established the Billerbeck Bakery, which distributed so many pretzels to residents that the local newspaper later dubbed Freeport the \"Pretzel City\". The city later capitalized on this nickname in 2003 by starting Freeport's first Pretzel Festival.<ref>{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Freeport is home to the oldest [[Carnegie Library]] in Illinois<ref>{{cite web
column4: publisher=}}</ref> and one of the first Carnegie Libraries designed by the [[Chicago]] architectural firm of Patton and Miller.  It was renovated into Freeport's City Hall <ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Freeport Carnegie Library-City Hall renovations on schedule
column11: archivedate=2017-03-15}}</ref> and City offices were moved to Carnegie City Hall in February 2017.

Before February 1893, a large square of land was purchased from the former Keller-Wittbecker farm in East Freeport.  Some of this land had recently{{When
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: date=September 2015}} been subdivided and platted as the \"Arcade Addition\".<ref>Reference to the ebook History of Stephenson County Illinois, Arcade Manufacturing Company, [http://www.ebooksread.com/authors-eng/addison-l-fulwider/history-of-stephenson-county-illinois--a-record-of-its-settlement-organizatio-wlu/page-64-history-of-stephenson-county-illinois--a-record-of-its-settlement-organizatio-wlu.shtml page 510] {{webarchive
column4: date=2014-08-13 }}.</ref> The Arcade Manufacturing Company had been in operation since 1885 when the previous [[Novelty Iron Works]] had gone out of business at the corner of Chicago and Jackson streets.  That earlier company began as early as 1868.  After the 1892 fire, the Arcade Manufacturing Company built an entirely new factory in the Arcade Addition of East Freeport, where they produced coffee mills and other metal products.

column5: title=U.S. Census website }}</ref> of 2000, there were 26,443 people, 11,222 households, and 6,845 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 2,316.9 people per square mile (894.8/km²). There were 12,471 housing units at an average density of 1,092.7/sq mi (422.0/km²). The racial makeup of the city was 81.77% [[White (U.S. Census)
column11: other races]], and 2.22% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)
column13: Latino]] of any race were 2.12% of the population.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: There were 11,222 households out of which 28.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 45.1% were [[Marriage
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: married couples]] living together, 12.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 39.0% were non-families. 33.7% of all households were made up of individuals and 15.1% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.29 and the average family size was 2.93.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: In the city, the population was spread out with 24.5% under the age of 18, 8.5% from 18 to 24, 27.8% from 25 to 44, 21.2% from 45 to 64, and 18.1% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females, there were 87.1 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 83.8 males.

The median income for a household in the city was $35,399, and the median income for a family was $43,787. Males had a median income of $35,870 versus $25,095 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $18,680. About 9.9% of families and 13.1% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 18.6% of those under age 18 and 9.5% of those age 65 or over.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: There were also special variants throughout the Type 1 production. Most distinguishable by paint schemes and trim, there were special versions called \"Sidewinder\", \"Sidewinder II\", \"Champagne Edition\", \"Champagne Edition II\" and the \"S\". The Champagne Edition II only came in white with black accents and a Zender front spoiler. On the NA models the 1980 \"S\" versions came in only three colours, Alpine White, Black and Mars Red with unique colour accents. This \"S\" model differed from the base model by having blacked out chrome trim, day glow additions to the exterior trim, Recaro designed sports seats, white letter tires, sport strips and a standard five-speed transmission. This was followed by the 1981 \"S\" versions which only came in Cosmos Silver Metallic, Cirrus Gray Metallic and Mars Red without the colour accents. Steel sunroofs were an available option on both the \"S\" non-\"S\" vehicles. Unlike the sunroofs on the second-generation Sciroccos introduced in 1982, these earlier versions only tilted open. They did not slide back but could be removed and stored in a special fabric folder and placed in the trunk hatch. Not forgetting the addition of the \"Storm\" models, available in two colours with a run of 250 cars in each colour.

The 1975-1978 model year USA vehicles had four-speed manual transmissions; for the 1979-1980 model years, USA vehicles were offered a five-speed manual transmissions as an option. In 1981 the five-speed became standard. The engine option was mostly limited to one, although it changed frequently over the years. The 1975 models are 1.5 L (1471 cc), followed by a larger 1.6 with {{convert

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: A heavily redesigned \"Type 2\" variant (internally designated ''Typ 53B'') went on sale in 1981, although it remained on the A1 platform. The second generation Scirocco, still assembled on behalf of Volkswagen by [[Karmann]] of [[Osnabrück]] (in the same factory as the first generation Scirocco), was first shown at the [[Geneva Motor Show#1981
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: 1981 Geneva Motor Show]] in March that year.<ref name=\"salon81\">{{Cite journal
column10: department = Salon 1981: Toutes les Voitures du Monde
column15: language = french }}</ref> Designed by Volkswagen's own internal design team, the new car featured increased front and rear headroom, increased luggage space and a reduction in the coefficient of drag. One feature of the Type 2 was the location of the rear spoiler midway up the glass on the rear hatch. A mid-cycle update occurred in 1984, which included minor changes over the 1982 model: removal of the outlined \"<small>SCIROCCO</small>\" script from the rear hatch (below the spoiler), a redesigned air conditioning compressor, and a different brake master cylinder with in-line proportioning valves and a brake light switch mounted to the pedal instead of on the master cylinder.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Halfway through the 1984 model year, a new space-saver spare wheel was added, that provided room for a larger fuel tank (with a second \"transfer\" fuel pump). Leather interior, power windows and mirrors, air conditioning, and a manual sunroof were options for all years. The 1984 model year saw the return of two windshield wipers (vs the large single wiper), absent since the 1976 models.

Eleven different engines were offered in the Type 2 Scirocco over the production run, although not all engines were available in all markets. These engines included both carburetor and fuel injection engines. Initially all models had eight-valve engines. A 16-valve head was developed by tuner [[Oettinger (tuner)
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Oettinger]] in 1981, with the modification adopted by Volkswagen when they showed a multi-valve Scirocco at the [[Frankfurt Motor Show#1983
column10: trans-title= Motor Show: The Valve War
column16: location = Brussels, Belgium }}</ref> It went on sale in Germany and a few other markets in July 1985, with a catalyzed model arriving in 1986. Displacements ranged from 1.3 liters up to 1.8 liters. Power ranged from 44 kW (60 PS) to 82 kW (112 PS) for the 8-valve engines and either 95 kW (129 PS) or 102 kW (139 PS) for the 16-valve engines.<ref>{{citation
column19: title = Scirocco: Aufregend vernünftig. Der Volkswagen Scirocco 1974—1992

These special models typically featured unique interior/exterior color combinations, special alloy wheels and had special combinations of options such as leather, multifunction trip computer and/or power windows as standard.

Six years after its launch in 2008, Volkswagen revealed the 2014 Scirocco face-lift at the [[Geneva Motor Show]].<ref>{{cite web
column5: publisher=Motor1}}</ref> On the outside the changes weren't obvious as Volkswagen installed only a slightly re-profiled bumper, new bi-xenon headlights with LED daytime running lights and they also tweaked the grille. At the back there were restyled LED taillights, along with a reworked bumper and boot lid. The changes carried over onto the range-topping Scirocco R as well.<ref>{{Cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{:
All models include standard six-speed manual transmission. The 1.4 TSI (162 PS) can optionally be fitted with a seven-speed DSG transmission, while the 2.0 TSI 200, 2.0 TSI 210, R 2.0 TSI 265 and 2.0 TDI are available with a six-speed DSG transmission.
The EA888 2.0 TSI uses an IHI K03 water-cooled turbocharger incorporated in exhaust manifold, while a BorgWarner turbocharger is used in EA113 2.0 TSI versions.
The 140 bhp 2.0 TDI engine is also provided with the [[BlueMotion]] Technology package. This package features stop start technology and regenerative braking to reduce emissions to 118 g/km {{CO2}}.
In the [[24 Hours Nürburgring]] in May 2008, three new Volkswagen Scirocco<ref>{{Cite web
column7: url-status=dead }}</ref> did very well in the field of over 200, among them many high powered cars, finishing 11th and 15th, with veteran [[Hans-Joachim Stuck]] driving both cars (and [[Carlos Sainz]] the slower one). The direct competitors, two [[Opel Astra]] H GTC driven by drivers selected from 18,000 hopefuls in a year-long TV covered process, were beaten decisively. In the 2012 edition of the [[Scandinavian Touring Car Championship]] [[Johan Kristoffersson]] won the championship for Volkswagen Team Biogas in a Scirocco.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The '''Volkswagen Scirocco''' is a three-door, four passenger (2+2), front-engine, front wheel drive [[sports car
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: sports]] [[coupé]] manufactured and marketed by [[Volkswagen]] in two generations from 1974 to 1992 and a third generation from 2008 until 2017. Production ended without a successor.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The Scirocco derives its name from [[Sirocco
Volkswagen began work on the car during the early 1970s as the replacement for the aging [[Volkswagen Karmann Ghia
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Karmann Ghia]] coupe, and designated it the ''Typ 53'' internally. Although the platform of the [[Volkswagen Golf
column3: Golf]] was used to underpin the new Scirocco, almost every part of the car was re-engineered in favour of a new styling (penned by [[Giorgetto Giugiaro]]) which was sleeker and sportier than that of the Golf. The Scirocco debuted at the [[Geneva Motor Show#1973
column6: title=10 revolutionary Geneva Motor Show debuts in the last 50 years

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Launched six months before the Golf, in order to resolve any teething troubles before production of the high volume hatchback started,<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=2010-10-09}}</ref> the Scirocco went on sale in Europe in 1974 and in North America in 1975. Type 1 models featured a range of four-cylinder engines with displacements from 1.1 to 1.6 litres, with a 1.7 also offered in North America, all featuring a single-overhead camshaft and two valves per cylinder.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The design of the vehicle combined with the lack of US [[Department of Transportation
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: D.O.T.]] approved rectangular headlights, made it necessary to have four round headlights, two for low beam use and two for high beam use for all the cars imported to USA. However, the European \"TS\" version, for which maximum power was listed as {{Convert
column6: abbr=on}}, was easily distinguishable from the less powerful \"L\" and \"S\" (50 and 70 PS) versions which came with just two rectangular headlights.<ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/> An automatic transmission option was added in January 1975.<ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/> Automatic transmission-equipped Sciroccos were generally rare outside of North America.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Blech der Woche (23): VW Scirocco Turbo – Das Auto, das es nie gab – Auto & Mobil

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The '''Scirocco GTi''' entered production in the summer of 1976, while the later cult Golf GTI wasn't unveiled until the autumn of the same year.<ref>[https://www.volkswagen-newsroom.com/en/stories/the-coupe-icon-2276  www.volkswagen-newsroom] The coupé icon- Retrieved 21 Feb 2020.</ref>

Its high-revving, 81 kW / 110 horsepower 1.6-litre engine featured mechanical fuel injection, 175/70HR13 tires on 5.5Jx13 wheels, a larger duckbill style front spoiler, a red frame for the grille, and the standard car's solid front brake discs were replaced with 9.4 in (239 mm) ventilated discs. Anti-roll bars were also fitted front and rear.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The Scirocco was sold in Japan at [[Yanase (car dealership)
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Yanase]] dealerships that specialize in North American and European vehicles with right hand drive starting in 1976, initially offering the TS trim package with the 1.4L engine and a 4-speed manual transmission. In 1977, the GTE and LS were offered with the 1.5L engine and the fuel injection technology from Bosch. The GTE was available with either the 4-speed manual transmission or the 3-speed automatic, while the LS offered the automatic only. Sales of the Scirocco continued for this entire generation to Japanese buyers, and it was in compliance with Japanese Government [[Vehicle size class#Japan
column3: dimension regulations]] which helped sales. The engines offered to Japanese buyers were the smaller displacement versions to reduce the annual Japanese [[Road tax#Japan

Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Oswald 1945 - 90 (vol 3)]], p 138</ref> However, air conditioning became available as an option on the domestic market in August 1975.<ref name=AutoMotoruSport1975>{{cite magazine
column4: title = Nachrichten aus der Technik: Klimaanlage für VW Golf und Scirocco (Technical news: air conditioning for VW Golf and Scirocco)
column9: date = 30 August 1975}}</ref>  The possibility to retrofit the installation, together with a larger battery, was offered to existing owners.<ref name=AutoMotoruSport1975/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: During the production of the \"Type 53\", there were subtle changes to the body and trim. On cars produced after the summer break in August 1975 (for the 1976 model year), the conventional two wiper system changed to a single wiper which parks on the passenger side of the windscreen, while the driver also benefited from improved, lighter, steering linkage.<ref name=\"ReferenceA\">[[#Oswald Band 3
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Oswald 1945 - 90 (vol 3)]], p 88</ref> In August 1977 (for model year 1978) the separate front side marker and turn signal, changed to a combination wrap-around orange lens. At the same time, behind the doors the B-pillar colour changed from body colour to black, which was thought to give the car a more pleasing profile.<ref name=\"ReferenceB\"/>   Other mid-life changes include the move from chrome bumpers with rubberised end caps to a plastic-coated one-piece wrap around bumper.<ref name=\"ReferenceB\">[[#Oswald Band 3
column3: Oswald 1945 - 90 (vol 3)]], p 89</ref> In 1979, the one-piece \"flag\" style outside mirrors transitioned to a two-piece shrouded mirror.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: There were also special variants throughout the Type 1 production. Most distinguishable by paint schemes and trim, there were special versions called \"Sidewinder\", \"Sidewinder II\", \"Champagne Edition\", \"Champagne Edition II\" and the \"S\". The Champagne Edition II only came in white with black accents and a Zender front spoiler. On the NA models the 1980 \"S\" versions came in only three colours, Alpine White, Black and Mars Red with unique colour accents. This \"S\" model differed from the base model by having blacked out chrome trim, day glow additions to the exterior trim, Recaro designed sports seats, white letter tires, sport strips and a standard five-speed transmission. This was followed by the 1981 \"S\" versions which only came in Cosmos Silver Metallic, Cirrus Gray Metallic and Mars Red without the colour accents. Steel sunroofs were an available option on both the \"S\" non-\"S\" vehicles. Unlike the sunroofs on the second-generation Sciroccos introduced in 1982, these earlier versions only tilted open. They did not slide back but could be removed and stored in a special fabric folder and placed in the trunk hatch. Not forgetting the addition of the \"Storm\" models, available in two colours with a run of 250 cars in each colour.

The 1975-1978 model year USA vehicles had four-speed manual transmissions; for the 1979-1980 model years, USA vehicles were offered a five-speed manual transmissions as an option. In 1981 the five-speed became standard. The engine option was mostly limited to one, although it changed frequently over the years. The 1975 models are 1.5 L (1471 cc), followed by a larger 1.6 with {{convert
column9: work = Road & Track's Road Test Annual & Buyer's Guide 1979
column13: page = 31 }}</ref> For 1978 Volkswagen reverted to a short-stroke 1.5 (now of 1457 cc), stating that this made meeting emissions requirements easier. Power dropped accordingly, down to {{convert
column18: abbr=on}} but with some fuel economy improvements.<ref name=RTbg79/> Buyers demanded otherwise and for 1979 the 1.6 (1588 cc) was reinstated, now with power up somewhat to {{convert
column24: R&T Buyer's Guide 1979]]'', p. 126</ref> 1981 USA models had a standard 1.7 (1,715 cc), all featuring a single-overhead camshaft and two valves per cylinder.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: A heavily redesigned \"Type 2\" variant (internally designated ''Typ 53B'') went on sale in 1981, although it remained on the A1 platform. The second generation Scirocco, still assembled on behalf of Volkswagen by [[Karmann]] of [[Osnabrück]] (in the same factory as the first generation Scirocco), was first shown at the [[Geneva Motor Show#1981
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: 1981 Geneva Motor Show]] in March that year.<ref name=\"salon81\">{{Cite journal
column10: department = Salon 1981: Toutes les Voitures du Monde
column15: language = french }}</ref> Designed by Volkswagen's own internal design team, the new car featured increased front and rear headroom, increased luggage space and a reduction in the coefficient of drag. One feature of the Type 2 was the location of the rear spoiler midway up the glass on the rear hatch. A mid-cycle update occurred in 1984, which included minor changes over the 1982 model: removal of the outlined \"<small>SCIROCCO</small>\" script from the rear hatch (below the spoiler), a redesigned air conditioning compressor, and a different brake master cylinder with in-line proportioning valves and a brake light switch mounted to the pedal instead of on the master cylinder.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Halfway through the 1984 model year, a new space-saver spare wheel was added, that provided room for a larger fuel tank (with a second \"transfer\" fuel pump). Leather interior, power windows and mirrors, air conditioning, and a manual sunroof were options for all years. The 1984 model year saw the return of two windshield wipers (vs the large single wiper), absent since the 1976 models. Eleven different engines were offered in the Type 2 Scirocco over the production run, although not all engines were available in all markets. These engines included both carburetor and fuel injection engines. Initially all models had eight-valve engines. A 16-valve head was developed by tuner [[Oettinger (tuner)
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Oettinger]] in 1981, with the modification adopted by Volkswagen when they showed a multi-valve Scirocco at the [[Frankfurt Motor Show#1983
column10: trans-title= Motor Show: The Valve War
column16: location = Brussels, Belgium }}</ref> It went on sale in Germany and a few other markets in July 1985, with a catalyzed model arriving in 1986. Displacements ranged from 1.3 liters up to 1.8 liters. Power ranged from 44 kW (60 PS) to 82 kW (112 PS) for the 8-valve engines and either 95 kW (129 PS) or 102 kW (139 PS) for the 16-valve engines.<ref>{{citation
column19: title = Scirocco: Aufregend vernünftig. Der Volkswagen Scirocco 1974—1992
column20: trans-title = Scirocco: Exhilaratingly sensible: The Volkswagen Scirocco 1974—1992

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Numerous trim levels existed, depending on the model year and market, and included the L, CL, GL, LS, GLS, GLI, GT, GTI, GTL, GTS, GTX, GT II, Scala, GT 16V and GTX 16V. Special limited edition models including the White Cat (Europe), Tropic (Europe), Storm (UK), Slegato (Canada), and Wolfsburg Edition (USA and Canada) were also produced. These special models typically featured unique interior/exterior color combinations, special alloy wheels and had special combinations of options such as leather, multifunction trip computer and/or power windows as standard.
Scirocco sales continued until 1992 in Germany, the UK, and some other European markets. The Scirocco was briefly joined but effectively replaced by the [[Volkswagen Corrado
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: Corrado]] in the VW line-up, although this had been on sale since 1988 and was aimed further upmarket.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The Scirocco continued to be offered to Japanese buyers, but only the GTi with the 1.8 L engine in either manual or automatic transmissions, but starting with 1986 only the automatic transmission was offered. It did continue to comply with Japanese Government dimension regulations.

Specifications in North America are somewhat different from those of cars sold in the rest of the world, due to the differing safety and emissions regulations in place there. In North America, 1982 and 1983 models produce {{convert
column9: abbr=on}} of torque. The engine code was EN. The 1984 models produce {{convert
column17: abbr=on}} of torque, the engine code was JH. In mid-1986, a 16-valve model was released in the United States and Canada, which included a full body skirt, larger rear spoiler, and tear-drop shaped wheel slots to distinguish it from Type 2 8-valve models. Sales continued until 1988 in the United States, 1989 in Canada, being effectively replaced in both markets by the more expensive Corrado.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: Launched six months before the Golf, in order to resolve any teething troubles before production of the high volume hatchback started,<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=2010-10-09}}</ref> the Scirocco went on sale in Europe in 1974 and in North America in 1975. Type 1 models featured a range of four-cylinder engines with displacements from 1.1 to 1.6 litres, with a 1.7 also offered in North America, all featuring a single-overhead camshaft and two valves per cylinder.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The design of the vehicle combined with the lack of US [[Department of Transportation
Mexican actress, singer and model}}: D.O.T.]] approved rectangular headlights, made it necessary to have four round headlights, two for low beam use and two for high beam use for all the cars imported to USA. However, the European \"TS\" version, for which maximum power was listed as {{Convert
column6: abbr=on}}, was easily distinguishable from the less powerful \"L\" and \"S\" (50 and 70 PS) versions which came with just two rectangular headlights.<ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/> An automatic transmission option was added in January 1975.<ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/> Automatic transmission-equipped Sciroccos were generally rare outside of North America.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Blech der Woche (23): VW Scirocco Turbo – Das Auto, das es nie gab – Auto & Mobil

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,TAnthony,"{{: The '''Scirocco GTi''' entered production in the summer of 1976, while the later cult Golf GTI wasn't unveiled until the autumn of the same year.<ref>[https://www.volkswagen-newsroom.com/en/stories/the-coupe-icon-2276  www.volkswagen-newsroom] The coupé icon- Retrieved 21 Feb 2020.</ref>

Its high-revving, 81 kW / 110 horsepower 1.6-litre engine featured mechanical fuel injection, 175/70HR13 tires on 5.5Jx13 wheels, a larger duckbill style front spoiler, a red frame for the grille, and the standard car's solid front brake discs were replaced with 9.4 in (239 mm) ventilated discs. Anti-roll bars were also fitted front and rear.
